description: “Khao Khlong Pad Gai” ( ข้าวกล้องผัดไก่ ) is stir-fried brown rice with chicken. The meat is stir-fried with garlic and then mixed with pre-cooked brown rice. Usually vegetables such as carrots, onions or baby corn are added. The dish is seasoned with a mixture of soy sauce, fish sauce and some palm sugar.
thaiName: ข้าวกล้องผัดไก่

description: “Khao Khlong Pad Goong” ( ข้าวกล้องผัดกุ้ง ) is fried brown whole grain rice with shrimp, eggs and vegetables. The rice is seasoned with garlic, soy and fish sauce as well as palm sugar when stir-frying.
thaiName: ข้าวกล้องผัดกุ้ง

description:
“Khao Khluk Kapi” ( ข้าวคลุกกะปิ ) is rice that is stir-fried together with shrimp paste. The dish is typically served with several side dishes that are placed in a circle around the rice.
Side dishes include cucumber pieces, shallots, dried prawns, green mango, chili peppers, omelet, fried pork, pork belly, Chinese sausage, or fried mackerel.
thaiName: ข้าวคลุกกะปิ

description: Khao khua" ( ข้าวคั่ว ) is the name given to roasted rice powder. For this, uncooked rice is roasted in a pan without oil together with various ingredients such as galangal, lemongrass or kaffir lime leaves and then pounded in a mortar. Glutinous rice is usually used for this, but other rice can be used. The resulting coarse-grained powder is used to season salads and other dishes.
thaiName: ข้าวคั่ว

summary: Sticky Rice in Bamboo Tube from Charcoal Grill
description: “Khao Lam” ( ข้าวหลาม ) is sticky rice that is mixed with coconut milk and other ingredients such as black beans and then grilled in a bamboo tube. The rice can be seasoned as a dessert with sugar or as a snack with salt. The name is composed of the words “Khao” for rice and “Lam” for “in bamboo tube”. The dish can also be found under the name “Khao Lam Dtat” ( ข้าวหลามตัด ).
thaiName: ข้าวหลาม

description: “Khao Lueang Up Gai” ( ข้าวเหลืองอุ๊ปไก่ ) is a northern Thai curry with chicken and tomatoes that is prepared with a paste made from dried chilis, garlic, Thua Nao and prawn paste. Traditionally, this curry is then served with rice that has been coloured yellow with turmeric. The dish also goes by the name “Khao Lueang Jan Gai” ( ข้าวเหลืองจันไก่ ).
thaiName: ข้าวเหลืองอุ๊ปไก่

description: "Khao Mun Gai" ( ข้าวมันไก่ ) is a dish with Chinese background where tender boiled chicken is served on aromatic rice. The rice used is cooked in chicken broth instead of water. Khao Mun Gai is typically served with a clear chicken soup with radish and a sour-spicy sauce. The dish is the Thai interpretation of “Wenchang chicken” (文昌雞) from Hainan in southern China.
thaiName: ข้าวมันไก่

description: "Khao Man Gai Thod" ( ข้าวมันไก่ทอด ) is a variation of Khao Man Gai where the chicken is deep-fried instead of poached. The crispy, deep-fried chicken is served on fragrant rice cooked in chicken broth. Like the classic Khao Man Gai, the dish is typically served with a clear chicken soup with radish and a sour-spicy sauce.
thaiName: ข้าวมันไก่ทอด

description: “Khao Man Kati” ( ข้าวมันกะทิ ) is a very simple dish where rice is cooked in coconut milk that has been seasoned with salt and sugar. This rice goes very well with fruits.
thaiName: ข้าวมันกะทิ

description: “Khao Mok Gai” ( ข้าวหมกไก่ ) is a southern Thai dish that consists of spiced chicken and rice that has been fried with turmeric and other spices. It has influences from Indian and Muslim cuisine and resembles biryani, which is why it is also called “Thai Biryani” in the West. The dish is often served with fresh herbs, fried shallots, cucumber slices and a sauce made from palm sugar, tamarind, chilis and a range of spices. The dish is also known as “Khao Buree” ( ข้าวบุหรี่ ).
thaiName: ข้าวหมกไก่

description: “Khao Moo Daeng” ( ข้าวหมูแดง ) is a Thai street food classic where red-marinated pork or “Moo Daeng” is served on rice. The meat is topped with a reddish sauce made from the meat’s marinade and sprinkled with sesame seeds. Traditionally, it’s also served with a halved hard-boiled egg and some cucumber slices.
thaiName: ข้าวหมูแดง

description: “Khao Moo Grob” ( ข้าวหมูกรอบ ) is a very simple Thai street food dish in which crispy deep-fried pork belly is served with rice. It is often served with hard-boiled eggs, fresh cucumber and a spicy dip.
thaiName: ข้าวหมูกรอบ

summary: Rice with two types of pork
description: “Khao Moo Grob Moo Daeng” ( ข้าวหมูกรอบหมูแดง ) is a classic street food dish in Thailand, where rice is served with pork belly and marinated pork. The dish is typically garnished with a hard-boiled egg and a few slices of cucumber.
thaiName: ข้าวหมูกรอบหมูแดง

description:
"Khao Niao" ( ข้าวเหนียว ) is the name given to steamed sticky rice in Thailand. This is a particularly gluten-rich type of rice that becomes slightly sticky when steamed. This allows the glutinous rice to be shaped with the hands and dipped into soups, curries and nam prik.
Sticky rice is widespread in Isaan and northern Thailand, which is due to its proximity to Laos, where sticky rice is an integral part of almost every meal. Traditionally, sticky rice is steamed in a bamboo basket called a “huad” ( หวด ). The curved basket, which is reminiscent of a hat, is placed on an aluminum pot filled with water called “Mau Niao” ( หม้อเหนียว ), from which the hot steam rises.
thaiName: ข้าวเหนียว

description: “Khao Niao Ma Muang” ( ข้าวเหนียวมะม่วง ) is a dessert made from sticky rice and ripe mango. The sticky rice is mixed with sweetened and lightly salted coconut milk to achieve a soft and sticky consistency. The finished rice is then served with mango slices and often topped with thickened coconut milk. The rice in this dish is often colored with pandan or blue clitoria.
thaiName: ข้าวเหนียวมะม่วง

summary: Sticky Rice with Longan and Coconut Milk
description: "Khao Niao Piak Lam Yai" ( ข้าวเหนียวเปียกลำไย ) is a Thai dessert in which sticky rice and peeled longan fruits are served in sweetened coconut milk. Often the sticky rice is coloured and coconut flesh is mixed in.
thaiName: ข้าวเหนียวเปียกลำไย

description: “Khao Ob Sapparot” ( ข้าวอบสับปะรด ) is fried rice with seafood and pineapple pieces that is baked in a pineapple half and also served in it. Depending on the recipe, raisins, ham, bell peppers, or pork floss are also used.
thaiName: ข้าวอบสับปะรด

description: “Khao Pad” ( ข้าวผัด ) is a typical leftover dish in which surplus rice is fried in a wok. In the simplest case, the rice is fried with garlic, vegetables, egg, fish sauce and soy sauce. However, there are also countless variations of this street food classic, in which all kinds of other ingredients such as meat, seafood, mushrooms, tofu, various curry pastes or certain sauces are used.
thaiName: ข้าวผัด

description: “Khao Pad Fak Thong” ( ข้าวผัดฟักทอง ) is jasmine rice stir-fried together with pre-cooked pumpkin. Both are mixed with garlic, scallions, and egg, then seasoned with fish sauce and various soy sauces.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดฟักทอง

description:
“Khao Pad Ga Prau” ( ข้าวผัดกะเพรา ) is a Thai wok dish in which chopped meat is sautéed with garlic and chilies before being mixed with pre-cooked jasmine rice. Both are then stir-fried together and seasoned with a mixture of soy sauce, fish sauce and chopped holy basil leaves. Alternatively, a ready-made “Holy Basil Seasoning Paste” can also be used for seasoning. The dish can also be found under the name “Khao Kluk Pad Ga Prau” ( ข้าวคลุกผัดกะเพรา ).
Rezepte
thaiName: ข้าวผัดกะเพรา

description: “Khao Pad Gaeng Keow Wan” ( ข้าวผัดแกงเขียวหวาน ) is fried rice that was originally prepared with leftover green curry. However, the dish enjoys great popularity and is therefore often prepared “fresh” with green curry paste, a little coconut milk and other typical ingredients for green curry.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดแกงเขียวหวาน

transcription: Khao Pad Gaeng Phed Plaa Tuna
summary: Fried Rice With Curry Paste and Tuna
description: “Khao Pad Gaeng Phed Plaa Tuna” ( ข้าวผัดแกงเผ็ดปลาทูน่า ) is fried rice with canned tuna. It is seasoned with red curry paste, garlic, light soy sauce and fish sauce. Depending on the recipe, some coconut milk is also added. Vegetables such as green beans or baby corn can be used. The dish can also be found under the name “Khao Pad Prik Plaa Tuna” ( ข้าวผัดพริกปลาทูน่า ).
alternativeNames: Khao Pad Gaeng Phet Pla Tuna
Khao Phat Kaeng Phet Plaa Thuna
Kao Pad Gaeng Phet Pla Thuna
Kao Phad Kaeng Phed Plaa Tuna
Khao Phad Gaeng Phet Pla Tuna
Kao Pat Gaeng Phet Plaa Thuna
thaiName: ข้าวผัดแกงเผ็ดปลาทูน่า

description: “Khao Pad Gai” ( ข้าวผัดไก่ ) is Thai fried rice with chicken, egg and vegetables. It is stir-fried in a wok with garlic and seasoned with a mixture of oyster sauce, soy sauce, fish sauce, Golden Mountain sauce and palm sugar.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดไก่

description: “Khao Pad Goong” ( ข้าวผัดกุ้ง ) is fried rice with prawns and finely chopped vegetables. It is stir-fried with garlic and then seasoned with a mixture of oyster, fish and soy sauce, palm sugar and white pepper.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดกุ้ง

description: “Khao Pad Gunchiang” ( ข้าวผัดกุนเชียง ) is rice that is fried together with the Chinese sausage “Gunchiang” and some vegetables. This fried rice is flavoured with garlic, white pepper, soy sauce and fish sauce.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดกุนเชียง

description: “Khao Pad Moo” ( ข้าวผัดหมู ) is Thai fried rice with pork, egg and vegetables. This is stir-fried in a wok with garlic, various types of soy sauce, oyster sauce and fish sauce.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดหมู

description: “Khao Pad Moo Grob” ( ข้าวผัดหมูกรอบ ) is fried rice that is prepared with egg, spring onions, diced vegetables and slices of crispy pork belly.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดหมูกรอบ

transcription: Khao Pad Nam Prik Na Rok
description: “Khao Pad Nam Prik Na Rok” ( ข้าวผัดน้ำพริกนรก ) is jasmine rice that is stir-fried in spicy Nam Prik Na Rok. The rice can be mixed with meat, beaten egg and various vegetables.
alternativeNames: Khao Pad Nam Prik Na Rok
thaiName: ข้าวผัดน้ำพริกนรก

summary: Fried Rice with Chili Paste and Basil
description: “Khao Pad Nam Prik Pao” ( ข้าวผัดน้ำพริกเผา ) is fried rice seasoned with a mixture of various sauces as well as the chili paste “Nam Prik Pao.” In addition to meat, seafood, or vegetables, fresh “Bai Horapa” basil leaves are mixed into the rice. The dish can also be found under the name “Khao Pad Nam Prik Pao Horapa” ( ข้าวผัดน้ำพริกเผาโหระพา ), which further emphasizes the use of basil.
alternativeNames: Khao Pad Nam Prik Pao Horapa
thaiName: ข้าวผัดน้ำพริกเผา

description: “Khao Pad Nuea” ( ข้าวผัดเนื้อ ) is a variation of Thai fried rice with beef. Besides the meat, the rice is also mixed with vegetables, eggs and spring onions. The whole dish is then seasoned with fish sauce, oyster sauce and some dark soy sauce. Often the rice is served with fresh cilantro, lime wedges, cucumber slices and a small bowl of Prik Nam Pla.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดเนื้อ

description: “Khao Pad Pak Dong” ( ข้าวผัดผักดอง ) or also “Khao Pad Pak Khad Dong” ( ข้าวผัดผักกาดดอง ) is fried rice with pickled mustard greens. The rice is stir-fried with garlic and finely chopped mustard greens and then seasoned with fish sauce and soy sauce. The fried rice is often served with fresh chilis, spring onions and lime. Depending on the recipe, the dish may also contain finely chopped pork.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดผักกาดดอง

description: “Khao Pad Pak Kanaa” ( ข้าวผัดผักคะน้า ) or simply “Khao Pad Kanaa” ( ข้าวผัดคะน้า ) refers to fried rice with Chinese broccoli. Often some pork is also mixed into this dish.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดผักคะน้า

summary: Fried Rice with Curry Powder and Chicken
description: “Khao Pad Pong Gari Gai” ( ข้าวผัดผงกะหรี่ไก่ ) is fried rice with chicken and finely chopped vegetables. The rice is seasoned with yellow curry powder, soy sauce, oyster sauce and fish sauce during stir-frying.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดผงกะหรี่ไก่

description: “Khao Pad Poo” ( ข้าวผัดปู ) refers to fried rice with crab meat. The rice is stir-fried in a wok together with garlic, eggs, and chopped vegetables, then mixed with crab meat. The dish is typically seasoned with a combination of fish sauce, soy sauce, and oyster sauce. In southern Thailand, the dish is also known as “Yam Pad Bpu” ( ยำผัดปู ).
thaiName: ข้าวผัดปู

summary: Fried Rice With Red Curry Paste
description: “Khao Pad Prik Gaeng” ( ข้าวผัดพริกแกงหมูสับ ) refers to fried rice that is stir-fried with red curry paste and other spices. Usually meat, seafood and vegetables are also mixed into the rice.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดพริกแกงหมูสับ

transcription: Khao Pad Prik Khi Nu Goong
description: “Khao Pad Prik Khi Nu Goong” ( ข้าวผัดพริกขี้หนูกุ้ง ) is a spicy variation of fried rice with prawns. The rice is stir-fried with garlic and then seasoned with soy and oyster sauce, palm sugar and a large amount of chopped bird’s eye chilis.
alternativeNames: Khao Pad Prik Khi Nu Gung
Khao Pad Prik Khi Nu Goong
Khao Pad Prik Kee Nu Goong
Khao Pad Prik Kee Noo Goong
Khao Phat Phrik Kee Noo Goong
thaiName: ข้าวผัดพริกขี้หนูกุ้ง

description:
“Khao Pad Rot Fai” ( ข้าวผัดรถไฟ ) refers to fried rice that is seasoned with dark soy sauce or fermented red tofu. Traditionally, the rice is prepared with pork, tomatoes and eggs, but can also contain other ingredients such as vegetables.
The name of this dish can be translated as “Fried Railway Rice”. The origin of the name is not definitively documented. However, it could be traced back to a very popular fried rice that was served in the early 20th century on the railway line from Bangkok to Hua Hin and contained luxurious ingredients for that time, such as butter and sauces from Europe.
Other theories see a connection between the rice dish and the construction of the “Death Railway” between Thailand and Myanmar, which the Japanese army had built by forced laborers and prisoners of war during World War II. During this inhumane tragedy, the prisoners were said to be happy about any meal, no matter how simple.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดรถไฟ

summary: Fried rice with northern Thai sausage
description: “Khao Pad Sai Ua” ( ข้าวผัดไส้อั่ว ) is fried rice prepared with sliced sai ua, spring onions and whisked eggs. The rice is also flavoured with fish sauce and soy sauce. Depending on the recipe, this quick dish can also contain various types of Nam Prik.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดไส้อั่ว

description:
“Khao Pad Sapparot” ( ข้าวผัดสับปะรด ) is fried rice prepared with pineapple, seafood and cashews. It is often served in a cut pineapple half.
Sometimes the rice served in the pineapple half is also called “Khao Ob Sapparot” ( ข้าวอบสับปะรด ). This name is also used for a variation of the dish where the rice is baked in the pineapple.
HistoryThere are various theories and legends about the origin of Khao Pad Sapparot. The makers of the YouTube channel “OTR Food & History” explore some of them in the following video.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดสับปะรด

description: “Khao Pad Tom Yum” ( ข้าวผัดต้มยำ ) is fried rice that combines the famous Tom Yum soup with the Thai staple food rice. Pre-cooked jasmine rice is stir-fried in a wok with seafood or meat, then deglazed with Tom Yum broth and seasoned with Nam Prik Pao and fish sauce. The broth is prepared beforehand with galangal, lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves, and chilis.
thaiName: ข้าวผัดต้มยำ

description: “Khao Phot Ping” ( ข้าวโพดปิ้ง ) is a Thai street food dish made from grilled sweetcorn, which is particularly popular in northern Thailand. The corn cobs are coated with a mixture of coconut milk, sugar and salt before and during grilling and then served with this sauce and some lime.
thaiName: ข้าวโพดปิ้ง

description: “Khao Rad Na Moo” ( ข้าวราดหน้าหมู ) is a Thai dish in which rice is served together with a thickened sauce. This sauce contains pork and mushrooms, is made with yellow bean paste, fish sauce, soy sauce and oyster sauce and is thickened with cornstarch. Depending on the recipe, the sauce can have a thick or soup-like consistency.
thaiName: ข้าวราดหน้าหมู

summary: Aromatic Noodle Soup from Mae Hong Son
description: “Khao Sen” ( ข้าวเส้น ) is a Shan noodle soup from the province of Mae Hong Son in northern Thailand. The broth is prepared with minced pork, tomatoes and fermented canned fish, which gives the soup its characteristic flavor. Thin Khanom Dhin noodles are used, which probably gave the soup its name.
thaiName: ข้าวเส้น

description:
“Khao Soi” ( ข้าวซอย ) refers to various soups from northern Thailand. The best known is probably the one prepared with coconut milk and a paste base. It is usually served with meat and cooked wheat noodles, which are often fried as well.
This creamy soup probably originated in Yunnan and was brought to northern Thailand by traders and refugees belonging to the Muslim Chin Haw tribe . In neighboring Myanmar, there is a very similar soup called “Ohn no khao swè” (အုန်းနို့ခေါက်ဆွဲ). To distinguish it from other soups with the same name, it is sometimes also called “Khao Soi Chiang Mai” ( ข้าวซอยเชียงใหม่ ), “Khao Soi Islam” ( ข้าวซอยอิสลาม ) or “Khao Soi Kati” ( ข้าวซอยกะทิ ).
There are also other Khao Soi variations without coconut milk. For example, “Khao Soi Mae Sai” ( ข้าวซอยแม่สาย ) from the border town of the same name is more similar to Guai Tiao Nam Ngiau and is served with rice noodles. As with Nam Ngiau soup, the origin of this variant is probably the Shan.
“Khao Soi Nam Naa” ( ข้าวซอยน้ำหน้า ) from the Chiang Khong area, on the other hand, is a clear broth with rice noodles served with a topping of minced meat and tomatoes, not unlike Nam Prik Ong. This variant is a typical dish of the Tai Leu, an ethnic group that also lives in areas of southern China’s Yunnan province, Shan State in Myanmar, and Laos.
One explanation for this great variation lies in the origin of the name “Khao Soi.” In the Lao language, it can be literally translated as “cut rice,” but this probably refers to cut noodles, which made their way from Yunnan in China to the southern neighboring regions. Thus, Khao Soi could also simply be regarded as an umbrella term for “noodle soup.”
SourcesThe assumptions mentioned here regarding the origin of the various soups called “Khao Soi” come from the following sources:
thaiName: ข้าวซอย

description:
“Khao Soi Gai” ( ข้าวซอยไก่ ) is a northern Thai noodle soup with chicken, prepared with coconut milk and a spicy aromatic paste. The soup is usually garnished with shallots, pickled vegetables, and fried noodles.
The exact origin of Khao Soi is disputed. Some theories suggest that it came to northern Thailand with Chinese Muslim immigrants from the Yunnan region. Others believe that the dish originated in neighboring Myanmar.
There are various regional variations of Khao Soi, which differ in the type of broth or noodles used. However, the best known is probably the “Khao Soi Chiang Mai” or “Khao Soi Islam” pictured here, which is made with coconut milk and egg noodles.
thaiName: ข้าวซอยไก่

description:
“Khao Soi Moo” ( ข้าวซอยหมู ) is a northern Thai noodle soup with pork. The coconut milk-based broth is prepared from a paste. The soup is usually served with pickled mustard greens, shallots, lime wedges, and fried noodles as a topping.
It is worth noting that this originally Muslim dish is so popular in northern Thailand that it is now also prepared with pork, which is very popular there.
Rezepteauf cookpad.com
thaiName: ข้าวซอยหมู

description:
Khao Soi Nam Naa" ( ข้าวซอยน้ำหน้า ) is a soup with clear broth and rice noodles, served with a topping of minced meat, garlic, dried chilis and fermented soybeans. Depending on the recipe, the topping may also contain tomatoes and is then very similar to the dip Nam Prik Ong.
This soup is considered a typical dish of the Tai Leu and other ethnic minorities, who are indigenous to the north of Thailand as well as areas in southern China Yunnan, the Shan state in Myanmar and Laos. This is probably why the dish can also be found under the name “Khao Soi Lao” ( ข้าวซอยลาว ).
thaiName: ข้าวซอยน้ำหน้า

description: “Khao Soi Nuea” ( ข้าวซอยเนื้อ ) is a northern Thai noodle soup with beef. It is prepared with coconut milk and an aromatic paste. The soup is typically served with shallots, pickled vegetables, and fried noodles.
thaiName: ข้าวซอยเนื้อ

description: “Khao Soi Yunnan” ( ข้าวซอยยูนนาน ) is a northern Thai noodle soup with a clear broth. The broth is prepared with various spices such as ginger, lemongrass, cardamom, star anise and coriander roots. This soup is usually served with chicken, a sour dip, peanuts, pickled leafy vegetables, limes and shallots. This soup came with Muslim traders from southern Chinese Yunnan to the Golden Triangle and thus also became popular in northern Thailand.
thaiName: ข้าวซอยยูนนาน

description: Khao Tang Na Tang" ( ข้าวตังหน้าตั้ง ) is a savoury-sweet dip that is typically served with rice crackers as a snack. The dip is flavoured with garlic, coriander root, fish sauce and palm sugar. The other ingredients can vary depending on the recipe, but often contain minced meat, chopped prawns and peanuts.
thaiName: ข้าวตังหน้าตั้ง

description: "Khao Tom Mad" ( ข้าวต้มมัด ) is a dessert where a mixture of sticky rice, coconut milk and other ingredients such as taro, banana or black beans is wrapped in a banana leaf and steamed. The dish can also be found under the shortened names “Khao Tom” ( ข้าวต้ม ) or “Tom Mad” ( ต้มมัด ).
thaiName: ข้าวต้มมัด

summary: Rice Soup With Minced Pork Balls
description:
"Khao Tom Moo Sap" ( ข้าวต้มหมูสับ ) is a clear broth with rice and coarse minced pork balls. The broth is seasoned with the “three friends” ( Sam Gler) garlic, cilantro root and white pepper as well as ginger and soy sauce.
The soup is often garnished with cilantro or spring onions as well as fried garlic or roasted onions. Khao Tom Moo Sap is a popular breakfast in Thailand, also because it’s a good way to use up leftover rice from the day before.
thaiName: ข้าวต้มหมูสับ

description: “Khao Yum Ko Yo” ( ข้าวยำเกาะยอ ) is a rice salad from Ko Yo Island in Songkhla Lake in southern Thailand. The rice is mixed with various fresh herbs, vegetables, rice noodles in coconut milk, prawns, chilli powder and coconut flakes, and dressed with a dressing made from fish sauce or Budu, galangal, palm sugar, lemongrass and kaffir lime leaves.
thaiName: ข้าวยำเกาะยอ

description: “Khao Yum Pak Dai” ( ข้าวยำปักษ์ใต้ ), or simply “Khao Yum” ( ข้าวยำ ) is a southern Thai salad made from rice and other ingredients. In addition to rice, the salad contains roasted coconut, a paste made from chilli, lemongrass and galangal, lime pieces, shallots, roasted prawn paste and fresh herbs such as kaffir lime leaves and wild betel pepper leaves. The salad can also contain fresh or dried prawns.
thaiName: ข้าวยำปักษ์ใต้

description:
“Khua Khae Gai” ( คั่วแคะไก่ ) is a stir-fry dish from Northern Thailand with chicken, vegetables and herbs. Although the dish is named after the wild betel pepper leaf, which is known as “Khae” (แค) in Northern Thailand, it also contains other herbs such as Cha-om or Saw Tooth Coriander.
The dish has its roots in the originally Burmese-influenced Gaeng Khae soup from Lampang Province, but was developed from a soup into a pan-fried dish and enriched with ingredients such as coconut milk, mushrooms, Thai eggplant, snake beans and palm hearts.
thaiName: คั่วแคะไก่

description: The southern Thai “Khua Kling Moo” ( คั่วกลิ้งหมู ) is a dry curry with chopped pork. The meat is stir-fried with a spicy curry paste and many chilies until it becomes quite dry. The addition of kaffir lime leaves rounds off the aroma at the end. The dish can also be found under the name “Gaeng Khua Kling Moo” ( แกงคั่วกลิ้งหมู ).
thaiName: คั่วกลิ้งหมู

description: “Khua Kling Moo Sator” ( คั่วกลิ้งหมูสะตอ ) is a spicy, dry curry prepared with southern Thai curry paste, chopped pork and stink beans. The whole dish is garnished with chilies and kaffir lime leaves. The dish can also be found under the name “Khua Kling Moo Sap Sai Sator” ( คั่วกลิ้งหมูสับใส่สะตอ ).
alternativeNames: Khua Kling Moo Spa Sai Sator
thaiName: คั่วกลิ้งหมูสะตอ

description: “Khua Kling Nuea” ( คั่วกลิ้งเนื้อ ) is a dry curry dish from southern Thailand that consists mainly of chopped beef. The meat is stir-fried spicy with southern Thai curry paste and several chilies, which usually makes the dish very hot. Typically, this curry is garnished with finely chopped kaffir lime leaves before serving. There are also variants of this dish where thinly sliced meat cubes are used instead of chopped meat.
thaiName: คั่วกลิ้งเนื้อ

description:
“Khua Kling Plaa” ( คั่วกลิ้งปลา ) is a dry curry from southern Thailand, prepared with chopped fish. The preparation is done by frying the minced fish with a southern Thai curry paste and a large amount of chili peppers. At the end, the dish is usually sprinkled with finely chopped Kaffir lime leaves, which provide a fresh contrast to the curry itself.
Rezepte
thaiName: คั่วกลิ้งปลา

transcription: Kor Moo Pad Thakrai Prik Thai Dam
description: “Kor Moo Pad Thakrai Prik Thai Dam” ( คอหมูผัดตะไคร้พริกไทยดำ ) is a simple wok dish where marinated pork neck is stir-fried at high heat together with a paste made from lemongrass, garlic and black pepper.
alternativeNames: Kor Moo Pad Thakrai Prik Thai Dam
Khaaw Muu Phat Dta Khrai Phrik Thai Dam
thaiName: คอหมูผัดตะไคร้พริกไทยดำ

description: “Kor Moo Yang Jim Jaew” ( คอหมูย่างจิ้มแจ่ว ) refers to marinated and then grilled pork neck from Isaan, which is sliced and served with spicy “Nam Jim Jaew” dip.
thaiName: คอหมูย่างจิ้มแจ่ว

description:
"Krueang Gaeng Gari" ( เครื่องแกงกะหรี่ ) is the Thai name for yellow curry paste. It is made from dried chili peppers, turmeric, coriander seeds and cloves, as well as other spices. The paste is also called “Prik Gaeng Gari” ( พริกแกงกะหรี่ ) or “Nam Prik Gaeng Gari” ( น้ำพริกแกงกะหรี่ ).
The intensity as well as the color of the yellow paste depends on the spices used. So curries made with yellow paste can vary in color from a red tone to a very bright yellow.
thaiName: เครื่องแกงกะหรี่

description: "Krueang Gaeng Keow Wan" ( เครื่องแกงเขียวหวาน ) refers to green curry paste. This is made from green chilies, lemongrass, galangal, garlic, shallots and coriander seeds, among other ingredients. This paste serves as the basis for green curry and gives it its characteristic heat and aromatic depth. The paste can also be found under the names “Prik Gaeng Keow Wan” ( พริกแกงเขียวหวาน ) or “Nam Prik Gaeng Keow Wan” ( น้ำพริกแกงเขียวหวาน ).
thaiName: เครื่องแกงเขียวหวาน

description: “Krueang Gaeng Khao Soi” ( เครื่องแกงข้าวซอย ) is a curry paste from northern Thailand that is used to prepare Khao Soi noodle curries . The paste is made from Thai chilies, shallots, lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves, turmeric and ginger roots, coriander roots, coriander seeds, black cardamom, coarse salt, and shrimp paste, among other ingredients. The paste is also known as “Nam Prik Khao Soi” ( น้ำพริกข้าวซอย ) or “Prik Khao Soi” ( พริกข้าวซอย ).
thaiName: เครื่องแกงข้าวซอย

description: “Krueang Gaeng Khua” ( เครื่องแกงคั่ว ) is a Thai curry paste that serves as the base for many southern Thai curries. It consists mainly of dried chili peppers, turmeric, lemongrass, shallots, garlic, and shrimp paste. This curry paste is also known as “Prik Gaeng Khua” ( พริกแกงคั่ว ) or “Nam Prik Gaeng Khua” ( น้ำพริกแกงคั่ว ).
thaiName: เครื่องแกงคั่ว

description: The curry paste called "Krueang Gaeng Massaman" ( เครื่องแกงมัสมั่น ) serves as the basis for southern Thai massaman curries. It consists of ingredients such as dried chili peppers, cinnamon, cumin, coriander seeds, cardamom and nutmeg, which are crushed in a mortar. This paste is also called “Prik Gaeng Massaman” ( พริกแกงมัสมั่น ) or “Nam Prik Gaeng Massaman” ( น้ำพริกแกงมัสมั่น ) in Thailand.
thaiName: เครื่องแกงมัสมั่น

description:
“Krueang Gaeng Paa” ( เครื่องแกงป่า ) is a variant of red curry paste that often uses fresh green chilies in addition to the typical dried chilies. Ingredients such as lemongrass, galangal and krachai are also used.
Depending on the recipe, these spices are roasted before being crushed, which gives the whole paste a more or less strong roasted aroma. The paste is also called “Prik Gaeng Paa” ( พริกแกงป่า ) or “Nam Prik Gaeng Paa” ( น้ำพริกแกงป่า ).
thaiName: เครื่องแกงป่า

description: “Krueang Gaeng Pak Tai” ( เครื่องแกงปักษ์ใต้ ) is a curry paste for various dishes from Southern Thailand. It is made from dried chili peppers, black pepper, galangal, turmeric root, garlic, shallots and other ingredients. This curry paste is also called “Prik Gaeng Pak Tai” ( พริกแกงปักษ์ใต้ ), “Prik Gaeng Phed Pak Tai” ( พริกแกงเผ็ดปักษ์ใต้ ) or “Prik Gaeng Kua Kling” ( พริกแกงคั่วกลิ้ง ).
thaiName: เครื่องแกงปักษ์ใต้

description: "Krueang Gaeng Panaeng" ( เครื่องแกงพะแนง ) is the Thai name for panaeng curry paste. It consists of dried chili peppers, coriander seeds, cumin, lemongrass, galangal and roasted peanuts, among other things. This paste gives panaeng curry its characteristic thick consistency and mild spiciness. Other names for the curry paste are “Prik Gaeng Panaeng” ( พริกแกงพะแนง ) or “Nam Prik Gaeng Panaeng” ( น้ำพริกแกงพะแนง ).
thaiName: เครื่องแกงพะแนง

description: "Krueang Gaeng Phed" ( เครื่องแกงเผ็ด ) is the name given to curry paste for red Thai curries. It is made from dried chilli peppers, garlic, shallots, lemongrass, galangal and other spices. Other names for this paste are “Prik Gaeng Phed” ( พริกแกงเผ็ด ) or, more rarely, “Nam Prik Gaeng Phed” ( น้ำพริกแกงเผ็ด ).
thaiName: เครื่องแกงเผ็ด

description: “Krueang Gaeng Som” ( เครื่องแกงส้ม ) is a paste for sour curries from central Thailand. It is prepared from dried chilis, white pepper, shallots, garlic, fingerroot and shrimp paste. The paste gives curries a reddish color and pleasant heat. It is also called “Prik Gaeng Som” ( พริกแกงส้ม ) or “Nam Prik Gaeng Som” ( น้ำพริกแกงส้ม ).
thaiName: เครื่องแกงส้ม

summary: Paste for Sour Curry from Southern Thailand
description: “Krueang Gaeng Som Pak Tai” ( เครื่องแกงส้มปักษ์ใต้ ) or also “Prik Gaeng Som Pak Tai” ( พริกแกงส้มปักษ์ใต้ ) refers to a southern Thai paste for sour curries. The paste is prepared from many fresh and dried chili peppers, turmeric roots, garlic and shrimp paste. It gives curries a yellow to orange color and extreme heat.
thaiName: เครื่องแกงส้มปักษ์ใต้

description: “Kuai Tiao Gaeng Nuea” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวแกงเนื้อ ) is a hearty beef curry based on yellow curry paste that is typically served with rice noodles, hard-boiled eggs and peanuts. Sometimes the dish is also simply called “Kuai Tiao Gaeng” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวแกง ).
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวแกงเนื้อ

summary: Noodle Soup with Moo Daeng and Wontons
description: “Kuai Tiao Giau Moo Daeng” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเกี๊ยวหมูแดง ) is a Thai noodle soup with clear broth. Besides the noodles, it is served with red pork slices (Moo Daeng) and wontons (Giau). The soup is usually garnished with scallions, cilantro and crispy garlic.
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเกี๊ยวหมูแดง

transcription: Kuai Tiao Haeng Nam Prik Pao
summary: Stir-Fried Rice Noodles with Chili Paste
description: “Kuai Tiao Haeng Nam Prik Pao” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวแห้งน้ำพริกเผา ) refers to stir-fried noodles that are stir-fried with the chili paste Nam Prik Pao. In addition to the noodles, this dish uses meat, vegetables such as pak choi, Chinese broccoli or Chinese cabbage as well as beaten eggs.
alternativeNames: Guai Tiao Haeng Nam Prik Pao
Kuay Tiao Haeng Nam Prik Pao
Kuai Teow Haeng Nam Prik Pao
Kway Teow Haeng Nam Prik Pao
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวแห้งน้ำพริกเผา

description: "Kuai Tiao Haeng Nuea Toon" ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวแห้งเนื้อตุ๋น ) is a noodle dish in which rice noodles are served together with tender braised beef. The dish is quite dry, which means that very little of the broth is used, in which the meat is often braised for hours. In principle, it is a dry variation of the “Nuea Dtun” stew.
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวแห้งเนื้อตุ๋น

description: “Kuai Tiao Khua Gai” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวคั่วไก่ ) are these fried rice noodles with chicken, egg and green lettuce, which is stir-fried as a vegetable.
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวคั่วไก่

summary: Soup with Pork and Rice Noodles
description: "Kuai Tiao Moo Toon" ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวหมูตุ๋น ) is a soup with pork and rice noodles. The broth is made from pork bones and seasoned with “Saam Gloe”, cinnamon, star anise, pickled garlic and other ingredients.
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวหมูตุ๋น

description: “Kuai Tiao Nam Ngiao” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวน้ำเงี้ยว ) is a northern Thai noodle soup with beef or pork. Other important ingredients include tomatoes, dried chilies, Dok Ngiew (cotton tree flower), Thua Nao Khaep and blood tofu, which give the soup its characteristic spicy flavor. The origin of this dish is probably in the Shan State in neighboring Myanmar. The soup is also known as “Khanom Jeen Nam Ngiao” ( ขนมจีนน้ำเงี้ยว ).
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวน้ำเงี้ยว

description: “Kuai Tiao Nam Sai Gai” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวน้ำใสไก่ ) is a Thai noodle soup based on a clear chicken broth and rice noodles with chicken as a side. The soup can also contain various other ingredients such as Look Chin and is garnished with fresh herbs. The dish can also be found under the shortened names “Kuai Tiao Nam Gai” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวน้ำไก่ ) or “Kuai Tiao Gai” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวไก่ ).
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวน้ำใสไก่

description: “Kuai Tiao Nam Sai Moo” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวน้ำใสหมู ) is the name given to a clear rice noodle soup with pork. In addition to the meat that is cooked in the soup, such soups are often served with various other types of pork, such as minced meat, meatballs or offal. Soups of this type can also be found under the shortened or reversed names “Kuai Tiao Nam Moo” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวน้ำหมู ), “Kuai Tiao Moo Nam Sai” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวหมูน้ำใส ) or “Kuai Tiao Moo” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวหมู ).
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวน้ำใสหมู

description: “Kuai Tiao Nam Sai Neua” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวน้ำใสเนื้อ ) refers to a clear Thai rice noodle soup with beef. Such soups are also known under the short forms “Kuai Tiao Nam Neua” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวน้ำเนื้อ ) or “Kuai Tiao Neua” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเนื้อ ) or the reversed name “Kuai Tiao Neua Nam Sai” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเนื้อน้ำใส ).
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวน้ำใสเนื้อ

description: The “Kuai Tiao Nuea Pueai” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเนื้อเปื่อย ) is a hearty braised dish where beef is braised together with star anise, cinnamon and other spices in dark soy sauce until tender. The whole dish is then served on rice noodles.
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเนื้อเปื่อย

summary: Rice noodles with minced meat sauce
description: Kuai Tiao Nuea Sap" ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเนื้อสับ ) is a dish made from wide rice noodles, topped with a sauce made from minced beef, tomatoes, shallots, oyster sauce and various soya sauces. The dish is typically served on a bed of lettuce or cabbage leaves. It can also be found under the name “Kuai Tiao Rad Na Nuea Sap” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวราดหน้าเนื้อสับ ) at .
alternativeNames: Guai Tiao Rad Na Nuea Sap
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเนื้อสับ

description: “Kuai Tiao Ruea” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเรือ ) means “boat noodles”. This dish is a hearty rice noodle soup with pork or beef. Its name comes from the fact that it used to be prepared on boats in the canals of Bangkok and sold from there. This is why it is also called “Boat Noodle Soup” in English. Pork blood is usually used in its preparation, which gives the soup its characteristic dark color
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเรือ

description: “Kuai Tiao Sukothai” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวสุโขทัย ) is a Thai noodle soup named after the historic royal city of Sukhothai. The soup contains rice noodles, minced meat, Moo Daeng, crispy pork belly, fish balls and eggs. It is based on a clear broth that offers a balanced flavour combination of sweet, sour, salty and spicy. The soup can also be found under the name “Kuai Tiao Tom Yam Sukothai” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวต้มยำสุโขทัย ).
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวสุโขทัย

summary: Sweet, Sour and Spicy Noodle Soup with Pork
description:
"Kuai Tiao Tom Yum Moo" ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวต้มยำหมู ) is a variation of the well-known Tom Yum soup, served with rice noodles and pork in various forms. However, unlike the classic Tom Yum, the flavor profile of this soup typically features a pronounced sweet component.
This type of noodle soup, sometimes also called “Kuai Tiao Tom Yum Moo Nam” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวต้มยำหมูน้ำ ), is particularly popular among young people in Thailand. This is possibly due to the diverse options for customizing the soup with various accompaniments like fresh chilis, spices, and condiments to refine and season it according to personal taste.
alternativeNames: Guai Tiao Tom Yum Moo Nam
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวต้มยำหมู

description: Guai Tiao Yentafo" ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเย็นตาโฟ ) is a noodle soup with rice noodles, The broth is flavoured with fish sauce, vinegar and red, fermented tofu. Fish balls or seafood are usually used as a garnish. Depending on the recipe used, clotted blood is also added to the soup in the form of cubes.
thaiName: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเย็นตาโฟ

description:
“Laap” ( ลาบ ) is a classic dish from Isaan, the northeastern region of Thailand. It’s made with minced meat, fish, or mushrooms. The minced ingredients are mixed with herbs, roasted rice powder, and coarse chili powder, and seasoned with lime juice and fish sauce.
Laap is also found in northern Thailand, but it’s prepared differently there as “Laap Lanna”. Today, Isaan-style Laap enjoys great popularity throughout Thailand.
thaiName: ลาบ (อีสาน)

description:
“Laap” ( ลาบ ) is a salad with minced meat that originally comes from the neighboring country Laos, but has spread throughout Thailand in different variations via Isaan and Northern Thailand.
Laap from Northern Thailand, sometimes also called “Laap Lanna” ( ลาบล้านนา ), is prepared with less or no acid at all. Instead, the aromatic, dry spice mixture “Prik Laap” ( พริกลาบ ) is used, which contains among other things cumin, cloves, star anise and long pepper. Northern Thai Laap is often prepared with raw pork, offal and blood.
thaiName: ลาบ (ล้านนา)

description: "Laap Bpet" ( ลาบเป็ด ) is a salad from Isaan. It is made from shredded duck meat. This is seasoned with various fresh herbs, spices and a mixture of lime juice, fish sauce and roasted rice powder.
thaiName: ลาบเป็ด

description: "Laap Gai" ( ลาบไก่ ) is a spicy salad from northeastern Thai cuisine. It is prepared from minced chicken and dressed with an aromatic mixture of herbs, various spices, lime juice and fish sauce. The roasted aroma of rice powder rounds off the flavour.
thaiName: ลาบไก่ (อีสาน)

description: “Laap Gai” ( ลาบไก่ ) is a spicy salad from northern Thai cuisine. It is prepared with minced chicken and dressed with an aromatic mixture of herbs and a specific spice blend. Depending on the recipe, fresh blood is sometimes added to this dish.
thaiName: ลาบไก่ (ล้านนา)

description: “Laap Goong” ( ลาบกุ้ง ) is a salad from Isaan where chopped prawns are mixed with fresh herbs, roasted rice powder, and coarse chili powder. The mixture is then dressed with lime juice and fish sauce. There are also variations of this salad that use raw prawns.
thaiName: ลาบกุ้ง

description:
"Laap Hed" ( ลาบเห็ด ) or “Laap Hed Ruam” ( ลาบเห็ดรวม ) is a salad with chopped mushrooms and fresh herbs, dressed with a mix of lime juice and fish sauce. It is seasoned with coarse chili powder and roasted rice powder. Depending on the recipe, the mushrooms are grilled before being chopped or fried in a chopped form.
A Laap Hed can be prepared completely vegan using soy sauce instead of fish sauce. There are also variations where ground meat is mixed with the mushrooms. Finally, “Laap Hed” can also refer to a salad where whole mushrooms are used and mixed with ground meat.
thaiName: ลาบเห็ด

summary: Salad with Minced Meat, Seafood and Mushrooms
description: “Laap Hed Khem Thong” ( ลาบเห็ดเข็มทอง ) is a Laap adaptation from central Thailand. The special feature is that enoki mushrooms and seafood are mixed into the minced meat.
thaiName: ลาบเห็ดเข็มทอง

summary: Salad with chopped mushrooms and glass noodles
description:
"Laap Hed Wun Sen" ( ลาบเห็ดวุ้นเส้น ) is a salad with chopped mushrooms, fresh herbs and glass noodles. Depending on the recipe, the mushrooms are grilled before being chopped or fried already chopped. The salad is seasoned with fish sauce, lime juice, chili powder and roasted rice powder.
Rezepte
thaiName: ลาบเห็ดวุ้นเส้น

description: “Laap Khao Phot” ( ลาบข้าวโพด ) is a salad with corn that is seasoned like a typical Laap from Isaan. The corn is mixed with fish sauce, lime juice, coarse chili powder, roasted rice powder and fresh herbs. In some recipes, tofu is also added to the corn.
thaiName: ลาบข้าวโพด

description: “Laap Moo” ( ลาบหมู ) is a salad from Isaan that is prepared with minced pork, fresh herbs, dried chili peppers, roasted rice powder, fish sauce, and lime juice.
thaiName: ลาบหมู

description: “Laap Moo Khua” ( ลาบหมูคั่ว ) or “Laap Khua Moo” ( ลาบคั่วหมู ) is a northern Thai minced pork salad that is dressed with the so-called Prik Laap ( พริกลาบ ) spice mixture and fish sauce. Unlike other laap variations in northern Thailand, the meat here is cooked and not eaten raw. The salad is then mixed with fresh herbs, shallots and fried garlic.
thaiName: ลาบหมูคั่ว

description: “Laap Moo Suk” ( ลาบหมูสุก ) is a minced meat salad from Northern Thailand that is seasoned with the so-called Prik Laap ( พริกลาบ ) spice mixture and pig’s blood. Unlike other northern Thai Laap variations, this salad is not consumed raw but is briefly stir-fried.
thaiName: ลาบหมูสุก

description: Laap Nuea" ( ลาบเนื้อ ) is a salad from Isaan that is prepared with minced beef, fish sauce, lime juice, fresh herbs, chili powder and roasted rice powder.
thaiName: ลาบเนื้อ

description: “Laap Plaa” ( ลาบปลา ) is a salad from northeast Thailand, prepared with chopped fish, fresh herbs, chilli powder and roasted rice powder and dressed with fish sauce and chopped galangal.
thaiName: ลาบปลา

description:
Laap thod ( ลาบทอด are deep-fried meatballs that are seasoned with the typical ingredients of a laap salad from Isaan. These include fish sauce, khao khua, coarse chili powder, shallots and fresh mint.
Types of MeatDepending on the type of meat used, the deep-fried meatballs can be named more specifically in Thai language:
Chicken: “Laap Gai Thod” ( ลาบไก่ทอด ) Pork: “Laap Moo Thod” ( ลาบหมูทอด ) Fish: “Laap Plaa Thod” ( ลาบปลาทอด ) Duck: “Laap Bpet Thod” ( ลาบเป็ดทอด )
thaiName: ลาบทอด

summary: Glass noodle and minced meat salad
description:
The “Laap Woon Sen” ( ลาบวุ้นเส้น ) is a variation of Laap Isaan, in which the chopped meat and herbs are mixed with glass noodles . The glass noodles give the salad a different texture, but also take away some of its spiciness.
Rezepteon pholfoodmafia.com
thaiName: ลาบวุ้นเส้น

summary: Sweet Coconut Milk with Green Pandan Noodles
description: "Lod Chong" ( ลอดช่อง ) or “Lod Chong Nam Kati” ( ลอดช่องน้ำกะทิ ) is a Thai dessert with green-colored noodles made from rice starch, served in sweetened coconut milk. The coconut milk is usually chilled with ice. The green color typically comes from adding an extract of pandan leaves. In addition to the coloring, this extract also provides a subtle but distinctive flavor note.
thaiName: ลอดช่อง

summary: Dip With Coconut Milk and Prawns
description: "Lon Kapi" ( หลนกะปิ ) is a dip with coconut milk, prepared with crushed prawns, tamarind and a rich spice paste. The dip is served together with raw vegetables and can also be found under the name “Kapi Lon” ( กะปิหลน ).
thaiName: หลนกะปิ

summary: Dip With Coconut Milk and Prawn Fat
description: “Lon Man Goong Savoey” ( หลนมันกุ้งเสวย ) is a dip prepared with coconut milk, prawn fat, minced meat, prawns and fresh ginger. It is typically served together with raw vegetables.
thaiName: หลนมันกุ้งเสวย

summary: Coconut Milk Dip with Vietnamese Sausage
description: “Lon Moo Yor” ( หลนหมูยอ ) is a dip with coconut milk and the Vietnamese sausage “Moo Yor”. The coconut milk is seasoned with shallots, Thai chilis, tamarind paste and palm sugar. This dip is usually served with fresh vegetables and sticky rice.
thaiName: หลนหมูยอ

summary: Coconut Milk Dip With Fermented Sausage
description: "Lon Naem" ( หลนแหนม ) is a northern Thai dip made from fermented sausage (Naem) and coconut milk. It is seasoned with coriander roots, shallots, chilis and palm sugar, resulting in a balanced combination of sour, salty and slightly sweet flavours. Lon Naem is typically served with fresh vegetables. The dip can also be found under the reversed name "Naem Lon" ( แหนมหลน ).
thaiName: หลนแหนม

description: “Lon Plaa Tuna” ( หลนปลาทูน่า ) is a dip in which tuna is simmered together with other ingredients such as shallots, lemongrass, garlic, galangal, and shrimp paste in coconut milk. This dip is commonly served with fresh vegetables such as cucumbers, long beans, Thai eggplants, or cabbage.
thaiName: หลนปลาทูน่า

description: “Lon Tao Hu Ji” ( หลนเต้าหู้ยี้ ) is a dip that is prepared with coconut milk, fermented tofu and various spices. Often minced meat or chopped shrimp are added to the dip before it is served together with raw vegetables.
thaiName: หลนเต้าหู้ยี้

summary: Dip With Ground Meat and Bean Paste
description: “Lon Tao Jiaw” ( หลนเต้าเจี้ยว ) refers to a dip prepared with coconut milk, ground meat and yellow bean paste or whole soybeans. This is usually served together with raw vegetables and can also be found under the reversed name “Tao Jiaw Lon” ( เต้าเจี้ยวหลน ).
thaiName: หลนเต้าเจี้ยว

description:
In Thailand, "Look Chin" ( ลูกชิ้น ) are balls made from different types of meat such as pork, beef, fish or prawns. The meat is finely chopped, mixed with flour, seasoned and then formed into small balls, which are then boiled or deep-fried. Look Chin are usually served in soups, curries or as a snack with a dip.
Specific Names Pork: “Look Chin Moo” ( ลูกชิ้นหมู ) Beef : “Look Chin Nuea” ( ลูกชิ้นเนื้อ ) Fish : “Look Chin Plaa” ( ลูกชิ้นปลา )
thaiName: ลูกชิ้น

summary: Meatballs in Sweet and Sour Sauce
description: “Look Chin Pad Priau Wan” ( ลูกชิ้นผัดเปรี้ยวหวาน ) is a Thai wok dish with Chinese roots in which meatballs are stir-fried together with pineapple, bell peppers and various vegetables in a sweet and sour sauce. The sauce is prepared from vinegar, sugar, oyster sauce, chili sauce and other ingredients. The dish can also be found under the name “Pad Priau Wan Look Chin” ( ผัดเปรี้ยวหวานลูกชิ้น ) or “Pad Priau Wan Look Chin Sapparot” ( ผัดเปรี้ยวหวานลูกชิ้นสับปะรด ).
alternativeNames: Pad Priau Wan Look Chin Sapparot
thaiName: ลูกชิ้นผัดเปรี้ยวหวาน

description: Look Chin Ping" ( ลูกชิ้นปิ้ง ) is the name given to grilled Thai meatballs. These are grilled on skewers and then served as a snack with various dips.
thaiName: ลูกชิ้นปิ้ง

description:
Ma Ho" ( ม้าฮ่อ ) are savoury snacks served on pineapple pieces and garnished with coriander greens and chilli rings. These appetisers consist of crushed prawns, peanuts, minced meat, Saam Gler and lots of palm sugar.
The name “Ma Ho” can be translated as “Galloping Horses” and is due to the fact that this dish probably came to Thailand with mounted traders from Yunnan.
thaiName: ม้าฮ่อ

summary: Green Mango With Sweet Fish Sauce
description: “Ma Muang Nam Plaa Wan” ( มะม่วงน้ำปลาหวาน ) is what Thailand calls sliced, unripe mango that is served with a dip made from fish sauce.
thaiName: มะม่วงน้ำปลาหวาน

description: “Makuea Yao Pad Tao Jiaw” ( มะเขือยาวผัดเต้าเจี้ยว ) is a wok dish in which eggplants are stir-fried together with yellow bean paste, garlic, chilli and other spices. At the end, the dish is mixed with horapa basil and the whole thing is then served with rice. Depending on the recipe, the eggplants are also mixed with minced meat during frying.
alternativeNames: Ma Kuea Yao Pad Tao Jiaw
thaiName: มะเขือยาวผัดเต้าเจี้ยว

description: “Mama Nam” ( มาม่าน้ำ ) refers to a soup made with instant noodles from the Thai manufacturer “Mama”. The seasoning of the broth and other ingredients can vary greatly depending on the recipe, but the “Tom Yum” style preparation seems to be popular. It is usually a very inexpensive soup that enjoys great popularity especially in Bangkok’s street food stalls.
thaiName: มาม่าน้ำ

description:
Bei “Mama Rad Na” ( มาม่าราดหน้า ) are instant noodles served with meat and Chinese broccoli in a sauce thickened with cornstarch. The sauce usually consists of broth, fish sauce, soy sauce, oyster sauce, and yellow bean paste. Pork or chicken is typically used as the meat.
Rezepte
thaiName: มาม่าราดหน้า

description: “Mara Pad Khai” ( มะระผัดไข่ ) is a simple dish in which bitter gourd is stir-fried with garlic and then mixed with egg. Depending on the recipe, the egg is seasoned with soy sauce, fish sauce, sesame oil, chilis or herbs. The dish is also known by the name “Khai Khon Mara” ( ไข่ข้นมะระ ).
thaiName: มะระผัดไข่

description: “Mara Yad Sai Moo Sap” ( มะระยัดไส้หมูสับ ) refers to bitter gourds that are filled with seasoned ground pork. These are then either steamed or fried and eaten as a snack, or cooked in a clear broth and served as a soup.
thaiName: มะระยัดไส้หมูสับ

description:
“Mee Grob Samun Prai” ( หมี่กรอบสมุนไพร ) consists of fried rice noodles that are mixed after frying with a sauce made from palm sugar, tamarind, lime juice and fish sauce. These noodles are then mixed with toasted chilis, kaffir lime leaves, lemongrass, cashews and other ingredients.
These “Mee Grob Samun Prai” are served either as a plate dish freshly prepared or in a cooled state as a snack, depending on the region. The dish can also be found under the name “Mee Grob Song Krueang” ( หมี่กรอบทรงเครื่อง ) and usually also contains meat, tofu and shrimp.
thaiName: หมี่กรอบสมุนไพร

description: "Mee Kati" ( หมี่กะทิ ) is a noodle dish made with thin rice noodles that are cooked in a mixture of coconut milk, water, vinegar, and sugar. Red fermented tofu or yentafo sauce is often mixed in to color the noodles pink. A thick coconut gravy seasoned with yellow soybean paste, tamarind, and palm sugar is served alongside and typically contains minced meat, tofu, shrimp, or a mix of these. The dish is commonly served with sliced omelette, bean sprouts, and chives.
thaiName: หมี่กะทิ

summary: Pork and Egg Drop Curry Noodles
description: "Mee Kati Isaan" ( หมี่กะทิอีสาน ) is a heartier Isaan variation of Mee Kati. It also uses thin rice noodles, but they are served in a rich, thickened sauce made from coconut milk, red curry paste, and yellow soybean paste. The sauce typically includes pork belly, minced pork, and egg drop.
thaiName: หมี่กะทิอีสาน

description: "Miang Gai" ( เมี่ยงไก่ ) is a popular Thai snack. Grilled or fried chicken is cut into bite-sized pieces and wrapped in leaves together with chopped ingredients such as cashews, chilis, lime pieces, shallots, dried shrimp, ginger, and a spicy sauce. The leaves can be wild betel pepper leaves or simple lettuce leaves.
thaiName: เมี่ยงไก่

summary: Snack in a wild pepper leaf
description: "Miang Kham" ( เมี่ยงคำ ) is a Thai snack in which ingredients such as dried prawns, roasted grated coconut, diced lime, shallots, ginger, fresh chilis and peanuts are wrapped in wild pepper leaves. It is served with an aromatic sauce made from various roasted spices, palm sugar and fish sauce as a dip.
thaiName: เมี่ยงคำ

description:
"Miang Plaa" ( เมี่ยงปลา ) is a dish in which cooked, grilled, fried or deep-fried fish is cut into bite-sized pieces and wrapped in wild pepper leaves together with a selection of ingredients such as peanuts, chilies, pieces of lime, shallots, dried prawns, ginger and a spicy sauce are wrapped in wild pepper leaves and eaten as a snack.
There are also variations in which rice noodles are added or the pepper leaves are replaced by lettuce or other leaves. The dish can also be found under the name “Miang Plaa Pao” ( เมี่ยงปลาเผา ). If a specific fish is used, its name can also be appended to the name of the dish, for example “Miang Plaa Thapthim” ( เมี่ยงปลาทับทิม ) or “Miang Plaa Salmon” ( เมี่ยงปลาแซลมอน ).
Rezepte
thaiName: เมี่ยงปลา

description: "Mok Gai" ( หมกไก่ ) refers to steamed chicken in Isaan. The meat is marinated in a paste made from lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves, coriander roots, garlic, shallots and Thai chilis and then cooked over hot steam. Traditionally, the marinated meat is wrapped in a banana leaf. Depending on the recipe, fresh herbs or vegetables such as banana blossom can also be mixed into the meat. The dish is also known as “Hor Nueng Gai” ( ห่อนึ่งไก่ ).
thaiName: หมกไก่

description: "Mok Hed" ( หมกเห็ด ) is a dish made of white mushrooms steamed with herbs and spices in banana leaves. When specific mushrooms are used, the dish can receive more specific names such as “Mok Hed Khon Kaau” ( หมกเห็ดขอนขาว ) or “Mok Hed Nang Fa” ( หมกเห็ดนางฟ้า ).
thaiName: หมกเห็ด

description: “Mok Normai” ( หมกหน่อไม้ ) is a dish from Isaan where bamboo shoots are mixed with various herbs, spices and other ingredients, wrapped in banana leaves and then steamed. Depending on the recipe, the bamboo shoots are also mixed with meat such as pork belly. Eggs and sometimes coconut milk are used for binding.
thaiName: หมกหน่อไม้

description: “Moo Dad Deaw” ( หมูแดดเดียว ) is marinated pork that is dried in the sun and then often deep-fried . This popular snack is often served and enjoyed with a spicy dip called “Nam Jim Jaew”.
thaiName: หมูแดดเดียว

description: Moo daeng" ( หมูแดง ) is pork that is marinated in a mixture of various spices and red rose tofu . The meat is then grilled or fried and the marinade gives it a characteristic red colour and a slightly sweet flavour. The Moo Daeng is a Thai variation of the Chinese “Char Siu” (叉燒) and literally means “red pork”.
thaiName: หมูแดง

description: Moo Grob" ( หมูกรอบ ) is the name given to crispy baked pork belly. The pork belly is often deep-fried to make it even crispier.
thaiName: หมูกรอบ

summary: Baked Pork Belly in Coconut Milk
description: “Moo Grob Nam Ma Prau” ( หมูกรอบน้ำมะพร้าว ) is a Thai dish with pork belly that is first braised in coconut milk and then baked in it until it becomes crispy. Both are seasoned with coriander roots, garlic as well as fish sauce, oyster sauce and soy sauce.
thaiName: หมูกรอบน้ำมะพร้าว

description: Moo Hong" ( หมูฮ้อง ) is a southern Thai curry from the area around Phuket that cannot deny its southern Chinese roots. It is similar to mhu palo, but uses fewer spices. Sometimes the mhu hong is thickened to such an extent that it is no longer recognizable as a curry.
thaiName: หมูฮ้อง

description:
“Moo Kratha” ( หมูกระทะ ) is a type of Thai fondue in which the ingredients are not only cooked in a broth, but also grilled on the grill surface of a special Mhu Kratha grill pan. The juices from the meat flow into the broth, making it ever more flavourful . All kinds of meat, seafood, mushrooms and various vegetables are used as ingredients. Mhu Kratha is usually accompanied by various sauces for dipping.
“Moo Kratha” can also be found under the name “Nuea Yang Gauli” ( เนื้อย่างเกาหลี ) which can be translated as “Korean-style crickets” and gives an indication of the origin of this type of food.
thaiName: หมูกระทะ

description: “Moo Lung” ( หมูลุง ) are fried meatballs. These are prepared from minced pork, chilis, tomatoes and various herbs such as coriander, kaffir lime leaves, lemongrass and lemon basil. The meatballs can also be found under the name “Jin Lung” ( จิ้นลุง ).
thaiName: หมูลุง

description: Moo Manao" ( หมูมะนาว ) is the name given to very briefly cooked pork, which is then “post-cooked” in lime juice, giving it a very special consistency and flavour intensity. The meat prepared in this way is then dressed as a kind of salad with lime juice, fish sauce, garlic and chilis and served with fresh herbs.
thaiName: หมูมะนาว

description: “Moo Pad Hed” ( หมูผัดเห็ด ) is a simple stir-fry dish made with pork and mushrooms. Both are stir-fried with garlic and seasoned with a combination of oyster sauce, fish sauce, soy sauce, and a pinch of sugar.
thaiName: หมูผัดเห็ด

description: “Moo Pad Nam Man Hoi” ( หมูผัดน้ำมันหอย ) is a simple dish where pork is stir-fried and finished with a thickened oyster sauce. Sometimes the dish can also be found simply as “Moo Nam Man Hoi” ( หมูนํามันหอย ), without the “Pad”.
thaiName: หมูผัดน้ำมันหอย

description: "Moo Pad Nam Prik Pao" ( หมูผัดน้ำพริกเผา ) is a Thai stir-fry dish where pork is stir-fried in chili paste and then deglazed with a mixture of various sauces. At the end, Thai basil leaves are mixed into the dish.
thaiName: หมูผัดน้ำพริกเผา

description: In “Moo Pad Pak Choi” ( หมูไก่ผัดผักฉ่อย ) pork is stir-fried together with garlic and pak choi. The whole dish is seasoned with a mixture of oyster sauce, soy sauce and fish sauce as well as a pinch of sugar. This dish can also be found under the name “Moo Pad Pak Kwang Tung” ( หมูผัดผักกวางตุ้ง ).
thaiName: หมูไก่ผัดผักฉ่อย

description: “Moo Pad Phed Kati Sod” ( หมูผัดเผ็ดกะทิสด ) is a wok dish where pork is stir-fried in red curry paste. The special thing about this dish is that a little coconut milk is also used. In addition to the meat, this dry curry can also contain vegetables such as snake beans or baby corn as well as chilli and krachai strips. Thai basil leaves are also mixed into the dish at the end.
thaiName: หมูผัดเผ็ดกะทิสด

summary: Pork in Sweet and Sour Sauce
description: “Moo Pad Priau Wan” ( หมูผัดเปรี้ยวหวาน ) is a Thai wok dish with Chinese roots. Here, pork is stir-fried together with pineapple, tomatoes and other vegetables as well as cashew nuts in a sweet and sour sauce. The sauce is prepared from vinegar, sugar, oyster sauce, sesame oil and chili sauce, among other ingredients.
thaiName: หมูผัดเปรี้ยวหวาน

description: The northern Thai “Moo Pad Prik” ( หมูผัดพริก ) is a simple wok dish in which pork is sautéed with long chilis, garlic and soy sauce as well as fish sauce. Sometimes you can also find the dish under the name “Pad Prik Moo” ( ผัดพริกหมู ).
thaiName: หมูผัดพริก

description: “Moo Pad Prik Gaeng Normai” ( หมูผัดพริกแกงหน่อไม้ ) is a stir-fry dish where pork and bamboo shoots are stir-fried together with red curry paste.
alternativeNames: Moo Phat Phrik Gaeng Naam Mai
thaiName: หมูผัดพริกแกงหน่อไม้

summary: Stir-Fried Pork With Three Best Friends
description: “Moo Pad Saam Sahai” ( หมูผัดสามสหาย ) is pork that is stir-fried with a simple seasoning paste made from coriander root, garlic and pepper. Additionally, baby corn and Chinese broccoli or other vegetables or mushrooms are stir-fried. The whole dish is finished with a mixture of soy, fish and oyster sauce.
thaiName: หมูผัดสามสหาย

description: “Moo Ping” ( หมูปิ้ง ) is the name given to grilled pork skewers. The pork is marinated, put on skewers and then grilled over charcoal. In Thailand, they are often served with sticky rice and a spicy dip as a snack at street stalls or markets.
thaiName: หมูปิ้ง

summary: Pork belly in a dark five-spice sauce
description: “Moo Sam Chan Palo” ( หมูสามชั้นพะโล้ ) is a stewed dish with Chinese origins. Pork belly is braised in a dark, aromatic sauce over a low heat for a long time. The sauce consists of a mixture of various soy sauces and is seasoned with a variety of spices, including the eponymous Chinese five-spice powder (palo). Typically, dried shiitake mushrooms and eggs are also stewed together with the pork belly. The dish can also be found under the shortened name “Moo Palo” ( หมูพะโล้ ) or as “Khai Palo Moo” ( ไข่พะโล้หมู ).
thaiName: หมูสามชั้นพะโล้

description: “Moo Sap Nueng Tao Hu” ( หมูสับนึ่งเต้าหู้ ) refers to seasoned minced pork that is cooked together with tofu over hot steam. Depending on the ratio between tofu and minced pork, the dish can also be found as “Tao Hu Nueng Moo Sap” ( เต้าหู้นึ่งหมูสับ ).
thaiName: หมูสับนึ่งเต้าหู้

transcription: Moo Sap Pad Kapi Sai Dok Khae
summary: Minced Meat in Shrimp Paste With Sesban Flowers
description: “Moo Sap Pad Kapi Sai Dok Khae” ( หมูสับผัดกะปิใส่ดอกแค ) is a simple wok dish where minced meat is stir-fried together with sesban flowers in shrimp paste. The whole dish is then seasoned with soy sauce, Golden Mountain sauce and a little palm sugar. The dish is also known under the name “ดอกแคผัดหมูสับ”.
alternativeNames: Mhu Sap Pad Kapi Sai Dok Khae
Mhu Sap Pad Gabi Sai Dok Khae
Moo Sap Pad Gapi Sai Dok Khae
thaiName: หมูสับผัดกะปิใส่ดอกแค

description: “Moo Satay” ( หมูสะเต๊ะ ) or “Sate Mhu” ( สะเต๊ะหมู ) refers to grilled pork skewers. The meat is marinated in a coconut milk marinade with turmeric and other spices before grilling. It is then threaded onto bamboo skewers and grilled over charcoal until juicy and slightly charred. It is usually served with a peanut sauce and cucumber relish.
thaiName: หมูสะเต๊ะ

description: “Moo Sawan” ( หมูสวรรค์ ) is a Thai snack made from thinly sliced pork that is marinated in a sweet sauce made from palm sugar, soy sauce, oyster sauce and spices such as cumin, coriander and white pepper. The meat is then dried and finally deep-fried. The name of this dish can be translated as “heavenly pork”.
thaiName: หมูสวรรค์

description: “Moo Thod Gratiam” ( หมูทอดกระเทียม ) refers to a stir-fry dish with sharply seared pork that is almost deep-fried in plenty of oil and seasoned with garlic. The dish can also be found under the name “Moo Pad Gratiam” ( หมูผัดกระเทียม ).
thaiName: หมูทอดกระเทียม

summary: Fried Pork with Garlic and Pepper
description: “Moo Thod Gratiam Prik Thai” ( หมูทอดกระเทียมพริกไทย ) is a stir-fry dish with fried pork that is almost deep-fried in plenty of oil and seasoned with garlic and crushed black or white pepper. The dish is also known as “Moo Pad Gratiam Prik Thai” ( หมูผัดกระเทียมพริกไทย ), “Moo Thod Gratiam” ( หมูทอดกระเทียม ) or “Moo Pad Gratiam” ( หมูผัดกระเทียม ).
alternativeNames: Muu Thaawt Gra Thiamm Phrik Thai
thaiName: หมูทอดกระเทียมพริกไทย

summary: Pork with Peanuts and Bamboo Shoots
description: “Moo Thong Pad Khing” ( หมูทองผัดขิง ), or simply “Moo Thong” ( หมูทอง ) for short, is a stir-fried dish where pork is fried with peanuts and bamboo shoots in a simple paste made from garlic, shallots, galangal, lemongrass and shrimp paste until golden brown. There are also variations of the dish using dried or fried bamboo shoots, which is then called “Moo Thong Pad Khing Grob” ( หมูทองผัดขิงกรอบ ).
thaiName: หมูทองผัดขิง

description: “Moo Toon Khing” ( หมูตุ๋นขิง ) is a Thai stew made from pork and ginger. For this dish, pork is seared together with a paste made from coriander roots, black peppercorns, and sea salt, then deglazed with a mixture of dark soy sauce, Golden Mountain sauce, fish sauce, and palm sugar and topped up with water. Dried shiitake mushrooms and ginger are then added before the stew simmers for a while.
thaiName: หมูตุ๋นขิง

description:
"Moo Toon Tao Hu Ji" ( หมูตุ๋นเต้าหู้ยี้ ) is a dish in which pork is braised together with fermented tofu in a mixture of galangal, lemongrass, coriander roots, pickled garlic, fish sauce and Thai chilis until it is tender. Spare ribs or marbled pieces of pork neck are often used for this.
Rezepte
thaiName: หมูตุ๋นเต้าหู้ยี้

description: “Moo Wan” ( หมูหวาน ) is a wok dish from central Thailand where pork belly is first stir-fried together with garlic and then cooked in a mixture of soy sauce, oyster sauce, pepper and lots of sugar.
thaiName: หมูหวาน

description: In Thailand, “Moo Yor” ( หมูยอ ) is the name given to a sausage that originally comes from Vietnam and is called “Chả lụa” there. It is made from minced pork and various spices. This sausage mixture is rolled in banana leaves and then steamed.
thaiName: หมูยอ

description: “Naem” ( แหนม ) is a fermented pork sausage that originally comes from Vietnam. Raw meat is mixed with rice, garlic and salt and wrapped in banana leaves. The fermentation process creates a sour taste that goes well with fresh herbs, chilli and raw vegetables. Naem is eaten raw, fried or used as an ingredient in various dishes. In rare cases, beef is also used, which is known as “Naem Nuea” ( แหนมเนื้อ ).
thaiName: แหนม

description: “Naem Pad Khai” ( แหนมผัดไข่ ) refers to fermented sausage that is stir-fried together with eggs, chilis and fresh herbs. The dish can also be found under the name “Naem Khua Gap Khai” ( แหนมคั่วกับไข่ ).
thaiName: แหนมผัดไข่

summary: Deep-Fried Sausage With Kaffir Lime Leaves
description: The hearty snack “Naem Thod Bai Makrut” ( แหนมทอดใบมะกรูด ) from northern Thailand involves deep-frying fermented sausage and then mixing it with also deep-fried kaffir lime leaves. In our regions, you can alternatively use coarse pork bratwurst as a substitute.
thaiName: แหนมทอดใบมะกรูด

description: According to the book “Thailand: The Cookbook”, “Nam Jim” ( น้ำจิ้ม ) is a “Very Spicy Thai Dipping Sauce” made from fish sauce, chilis, garlic and lime. However, it may simply be a regional name for “Prik Nam Plaa”, a spicy sauce with the same ingredients.
thaiName: น้ำจิ้ม

description: “Nam Jim Gai” ( น้ำจิ้มไก่ ) is a spicy dip that is often served with grilled or fried chicken. It consists of a mixture of chili, garlic, lime juice, fish sauce and a large amount of sugar, which gives the dip a balanced combination of heat, acidity, sweetness and umami.
thaiName: น้ำจิ้มไก่

description: "Nam Jim Jeaw" ( น้ำจิ้มแจ่ว ) ist ein scharfer Dip aus dem Isaan, der hervorragend zu Fleisch passt. Er besteht aus geröstetem Reispulver, Fischsoße, Limettensaft, gehacktem Koriander und Chilipulver. Nam Jim Jeaw hat einen intensiven, rauchigen und scharfen Geschmack, der gut mit gegrillten Speisen harmoniert.
thaiName: น้ำจิ้มแจ่ว

description: “Nam Jim Look Chin” ( น้ำจิ้มลูกชิ้น ) is a dipping sauce typically served with Look Chin Ping (grilled meatballs). It is made from tamarind paste, garlic, shallots, coriander roots, fish sauce, sugar, and chili flakes. Often this dipping sauce is thickened with tapioca starch, creating a syrupy, sticky consistency.
thaiName: น้ำจิ้มลูกชิ้น

description: “Nam Jim Moo Kratha” ( น้ำจิ้มหมูกระทะ ) is a Thai dip specifically used for the Thai BBQ “Moo Kratha”. It consists of ingredients such as Sriracha sauce, vinegar, ketchup, sugar, garlic and chopped Thai chilis. The dip has a balanced sweet-sour and spicy flavor that pairs well with grilled meat and vegetables.
thaiName: น้ำจิ้มหมูกระทะ

description: “Nam Jim Prik Bon” ( น้ำจิ้มพริกป่น ) is a simple dip made from crushed garlic, chili powder, fish sauce, lime juice and palm sugar.
thaiName: น้ำจิ้มพริกป่น

description: “Nam Jim Satay” ( น้ำจิ้มสะเต๊ะ ) is a Thai peanut dip that is typically served with grilled meat skewers. It is made from roasted peanuts, coconut milk, red curry paste, palm sugar and other ingredients. The dip has a creamy consistency and a balanced, sweet-earthy flavor.
thaiName: น้ำจิ้มสะเต๊ะ

description: "Nam Jim Suki" ( น้ำจิ้มสุกี้ ) refers to the Thai interpretation of a Japanese sukiyaki sauce. This sauce is made with ingredients such as fresh chilis, chili sauce, pickled garlic, fermented tofu and crushed sesame seeds, depending on the recipe. It is often served with grilled meat and hotpot dishes.
thaiName: น้ำจิ้มสุกี้

summary: Spicy dip for fish and seafood
description: Nam Jim Talee" ( น้ำจิ้มทะเล ) is a dip that is served with seafood and fish. It typically consists of a mixture of chopped garlic, coriander greens, fresh chilies, lime juice, fish sauce and palm sugar. Another common name is “Nam Jim Seafood” ( น้ำจิ้มซีฟู้ด ).
thaiName: น้ำจิ้มทะเล

description: “Nam Jim Thua” ( น้ำจิ้มถั่ว ), or in its full form also “Nam Jim Thua Li Song” ( น้ำจิ้มถั่วลิสง ), refers to a Northern Thai dip made with peanuts, green chilis, lime, fish sauce, ginger and palm sugar. This dip is also known as “Nam Prik Thua Dan” ( น้ำพริกถั่วดัน ).
thaiName: น้ำจิ้มถั่ว

description:
"Nam Makham Piak" ( น้ำมะขามเปียก ) or simply “Nam Makham” ( น้ำมะขาม ) refers to tamarind water in Thai cuisine. This is an extract obtained from sour tamarind, made by soaking tamarind pulp in warm water, pressing it, and removing the fibers and seeds.
In Thai recipes, “Nam Makham” or “Nam Makham Piak” almost always refers to this tamarind water, not the concentrated pulp itself. Tamarind water can be used directly and allows for precise dosing of acidity.
The “tamarind paste” available in stores does not necessarily correspond to the Thai understanding of “Nam Makham Piak.” It is usually concentrated tamarind pulp, called “Nuea Makham” ( เนื้อมะขาม ) in Thai, or industrially produced tamarind concentrates that are very sour. For authentic results, store-bought tamarind paste should first be processed into tamarind water and then used like Nam Makham Piak.
thaiName: น้ำมะขามเปียก

description: “Nam Plaa Wan” ( น้ำปลาหวาน ) is what Thailand calls a dip prepared with fish sauce, palm sugar, prawn paste or dried prawns as well as shallots.
thaiName: น้ำปลาหวาน

description:
“Nam Prik Aep Thua Nao” ( น้ำพริกแอ็บบถั่วเน่า ) is a Northern Thai dip where fermented soy beans are pounded and mixed with chilies, garlic, salt and fermented fish sauce in a mortar.
This usually very spicy dip is served together with raw or steamed vegetables, such as snake beans, cucumbers or eggplants as well as sticky rice.
thaiName: น้ำพริกแออบบถั่วเน่า

description:
“Nam Prik Hed” ( น้ำพริกเห็ด ) is a Thai dip with mushrooms. The grilled or steamed mushrooms are pounded together with chilis, garlic, shallots and other ingredients in a mortar. This mixture is seasoned with fish sauce, lime juice and optionally shrimp paste.
This dip is served with sticky rice as well as raw or steamed vegetables. Depending on the region and recipe, various types of mushrooms can be used, from fresh forest mushrooms to dried mushrooms.
thaiName: น้ำพริกเห็ด

description: “Nam Prik Kapi” ( น้ำพริกกะปิ ) is a spicy dip with shrimp paste, garlic, chilis, lime juice and palm sugar. It is traditionally served together with raw vegetables or grilled fish.
thaiName: น้ำพริกกะปิ

description: “Nam Prik Kha” ( น้ำพริกข่า ) is a northern Thai dip made from roasted galangal, dried chilli peppers, garlic and salt. It is usually served as a spicy side dish with fresh or steamed vegetables, mushrooms or sticky rice.
thaiName: น้ำพริกข่า

summary: Dip With Green Chilis and Pork Rinds
description: “Nam Prik Khaep Moo” ( น้ำพริกแคบหมู ) is a variation of Nam Prik Noom in which deep-fried pork rinds (Khaep Moo) are additionally used. The crispy pork rinds are pounded together with grilled green chilis, shallots, garlic and other ingredients in a mortar.
thaiName: น้ำพริกแคบหมู

description:
“Nam Prik Khing” ( น้ำพริกขิง ) is a northern Thai dip made from ginger, chilis, coriander roots, fish sauce and fermented soybeans. It is often served with raw vegetables or grilled meat.
Rezepte
thaiName: น้ำพริกขิง

description: “Nam Prik Ma Muang” ( น้ำพริกมะม่วง ) is a spicy dip where pieces of unripe mango are pounded together with chilis, garlic, shrimp paste and palm sugar in a mortar to form a coarse paste. This is then mixed with fish sauce and lime juice and finally served together with raw vegetables as a dip.
thaiName: น้ำพริกมะม่วง

description: “Nam Prik Makuea Thet” ( น้ำพริกมะเขือเทศ ) is a dip from northern Thailand. To make it, tomatoes, chilis, garlic, lemongrass and shallots are roasted and then pounded in a mortar.
thaiName: น้ำพริกมะเขือเทศ

description: “Nam Prik Makuea Yao” ( น้ำพริกมะเขือยาว ) is a northern Thai dip made from grilled eggplants, chilis, garlic and fish sauce. All the ingredients are crushed in a mortar. Depending on the recipe, chopped meat can also be used for the dip. Nam Prik Makuea Yao is typically served with fresh vegetables and sticky rice. The dip can also be found under the name “Tam Makuea” ( ตำมะเขือ ).
thaiName: น้ำพริกมะเขือยาว

description: “Nam Prik Na Rok” ( น้ำพริกนรก ) is a spicy Thai paste that is often translated as “chili paste from hell”. The paste can be very dry depending on the recipe and would be described more as very coarse chili powder in our context. It is made from dried chilis, shrimp or fish, shallots, garlic, fish sauce and sugar. Nam Prik Na Rok is usually very spicy and is traditionally eaten with cooked rice or as a dip for vegetables or fruit.
thaiName: น้ำพริกนรก

summary: Chilli Dip With Fermented Leafy Vegetables
description:
“Nam Prik Nam Pak” ( น้ำพริกน้ำผัก ) is a northern Thai dip made from freshly fermented leafy vegetables, chilis, garlic and finely chopped meat or fish. This impresses with a robust mixture of salty, sour and spicy flavours. The dip is often served with fresh or steamed vegetables and sticky rice.
Depending on the recipe, it is a more or less dry dip. The name is composed of two parts: “Nam Prik” and “Nam Pak”. The former means “spicy dip” and the latter “pickled or fermented vegetables”.
thaiName: น้ำพริกน้ำผัก

description:
"Nam Prik Noom" ( น้ำพริกหนุ่ม ) is a dip made from fresh roasted green chilis, garlic, shallots, cilantro and lime juice, among other ingredients. It is often served with raw vegetables or grilled meat.
In Isaan, this dip is also found under the name “Jaew Mak Prik” ( แจ่วมักพริก ), but is prepared somewhat differently there - for example, plaa ra is used instead of shrimp paste.
thaiName: น้ำพริกหนุ่ม

description: “Nam Prik Normai Dong” ( น้ำพริกหน่อไม้ดอง ) is a spicy dip made from cooked, pickled bamboo shoots, garlic, chilies and salt. All ingredients are pounded together in a mortar. The garlic and chilies are grilled before pounding, which gives the dip a certain roasted aroma. Depending on the recipe, minced meat can also be mixed into the dip. Whether with or without meat, it is typically eaten with raw vegetables and rice.
thaiName: น้ำพริกหน่อไม้ดอง

summary: Chilli Dip with Minced Meat and Tomatoes
description: Nam Prik Ong ( น้ำพริกอ่อง ) is a northern Thai dip made from minced pork and tomatoes. It is prepared with a paste made from dried chilis, garlic, lemongrass, shallots and shrimp paste or fermented soya beans “Thua Nao” (ถั่วเน่า). The dip is usually served with raw vegetables or sticky rice.
thaiName: น้ำพริกอ่อง

description:
"Nam Prik Pao" ( น้ำพริกเผา ) is a Thai chili paste made from dried chilies, garlic, shallots and shrimp paste, among other things. All the ingredients are roasted and then processed into a thick, spicy paste. The finished paste is often used as a spice or ingredient in various Thai dishes to give them depth and spiciness.
Rezepte
thaiName: น้ำพริกเผา

description: “Nam Prik Sok Khai” ( น้ำพริกซอกไข่ ) is a dip prepared from dried chilis, garlic, shallots, pepper, fish sauce, lime juice and hard-boiled eggs. The finished dip is served together with raw or steamed vegetables and can also be found under the name “Nam Prik Khai Tom” ( น้ำพริกไข่ต้ม ).
thaiName: น้ำพริกซอกไข่

summary: Spicy Dip with Yard Long Beans
description: “Nam Prik Thua Fak Yao” ( น้ำพริกถั่วฝักยาว ) is a dip from Northern Thailand made from yard long beans, roasted garlic, chilis, and shallots. All ingredients are pounded into a paste in a mortar. This Nam Prik can be served with grilled meat or fish, or simply with sticky rice.
thaiName: น้ำพริกถั่วฝักยาว

description: “Nam Prik Thua Nao Khaep” ( น้ำพริกถั่วเน่าแคบ ) is a simple dip where dried, fermented soybeans are pounded together with garlic, chilis, and salt in a mortar.
thaiName: น้ำพริกถั่วเน่าแคบ

description:
"Nam Sot Pad" ( น้ำซอสผัด ) or “Sot Pad” for short ( ซอสผัด ) is the name given to the basic sauce for many Thai stir-fry dishes. It is usually a mixture of oyster sauce, soy sauce and fish sauce. This sauce can be mixed in advance.
When preparing certain stir-fry dishes, palm sugar, white pepper, golden mountain sauce, yellow bean paste or other spices are mixed in as required before the sauce mixture is used for seasoning.
thaiName: น้ำซอสผัด

description: “Nam Thakrai” ( น้ำตะไคร้ ) is a popular Thai refreshing drink made from fresh lemongrass leaves, which is served both hot as tea and cold as a refreshing lemonade. In addition to the lemongrass, the drink also contains a little salt and sugar.
thaiName: น้ำตะไคร้

description: “Nam Tok Bpet” ( น้ำตกเป็ด ) is a salad with grilled duck breast from Isaan. The meat is cut into thin slices and mixed with fresh herbs like mint and coriander. The salad is dressed with a mixture of lime juice, fish sauce and coarse chilli powder and garnished with toasted rice powder. The salad can also be found under the name “Nam Tok Bpet Yang” ( น้ำตกเป็ดย่าง ). This emphasises that it is grilled duck.
thaiName: น้ำตกเป็ด

description: “Nam Tok Gai Yang” ( น้ำตกไก่ย่าง ) is a Thai salad where grilled chicken is dressed with lime juice, fish sauce, chilli powder and toasted rice powder. The meat is then mixed with chopped spring onions, shallots and fresh mint or other herbs.
thaiName: น้ำตกไก่ย่าง

description: "Nam Tok Hed" ( น้ำตกเห็ด ) is a salad made from grilled mushrooms that are dressed with lime juice, fish sauce, chilli powder and toasted rice powder. This salad is then garnished with chopped spring onions, shallots and fresh mint and other herbs. Sometimes this salad is also called “Yam Hed Nam Tok” ( ยำเห็ดน้ำตก ) or, confusingly, “Laap Hed Ruam” ( ลาบเห็ดรวม ).
thaiName: น้ำตกเห็ด

description: “Nam Tok Moo” ( น้ำตกหมู ) is a salad where grilled pork is dressed with lime juice, fish sauce, chili powder and roasted rice powder. The whole dish is garnished with chopped spring onions, shallots and fresh mint or other herbs. Sometimes this salad is also called “Nam Tok Moo Yang” ( น้ำตกหมูย่าง ) or the components of the name are reversed.
thaiName: น้ำตกหมู

description: "Nam Tok Nuea" ( น้ำตกเนื้อ ) is a salad in which grilled beef is dressed with lime juice, fish sauce, chilli powder and roasted rice powder. The salad is then mixed with chopped spring onions, shallots and fresh mint or other herbs.
thaiName: น้ำตกเนื้อ

description: “Nam Yum” ( น้ำยำ ) is a spicy Thai salad dressing that typically consists of fish sauce, lime juice and palm sugar. These ingredients are often supplemented with tamarind paste, garlic, chilis or shallots.
thaiName: น้ำยำ

description: "Nuea Dad Deaw" ( เนื้อแดดเดียว ) is sun-dried beef. The meat is cut into thin strips, marinated, and then dried for several hours in the sun or a dehydrator. Afterwards, the dried meat is deep-fried. It is usually served with a spicy dipping sauce and sticky rice.
alternativeNames: Nuea Ded Diau - Nua Ded Diau
thaiName: เนื้อแดดเดียว

description: “Nuea Pad Brokoli” ( เนื้อผัดบรอคโคลี่ ) is the Thai adaptation of the American-Chinese classic “Beef & Broccoli”. Marinated beef is seared at high heat and then finished cooking in a thickened sauce made from soy sauce, oyster sauce, fish sauce and white pepper, along with blanched broccoli.
thaiName: เนื้อผัดบรอคโคลี่

transcription: Nuea Pad Kanaa Nam Man Hoi
summary: Stir-Fried Beef With Chinese Broccoli in Oyster Sauce
description: “Nuea Pad Kanaa Nam Man Hoi” ( เนื้อผัดคะน้าน้ำมันหอย ) is a classic wok dish where beef is stir-fried together with Chinese broccoli (Kanaa) and refined with a thick oyster sauce.
alternativeNames: Nuea Phat Kanaa Nam Man Hoi
Nuea Phad Kanaa Nam Man Hoi
Neua Pad Kanaa Nam Man Hoi
Neua Phat Kanaa Nam Man Hoi
thaiName: เนื้อผัดคะน้าน้ำมันหอย

description: “Nuea Pad Kha Min” ( เนื้อผัดขมิ้น ) is a southern Thai dish where beef is braised in a mixture of yellow curry paste and fresh turmeric root, which gives it a vibrant yellow color. After frying the meat together with the mentioned spices, shallots, Thai chilis, soy sauce, oyster sauce and palm sugar are added before everything braises for a certain time. The dish is served with finely shredded kaffir lime leaves and Thai jasmine rice.
thaiName: เนื้อผัดขมิ้น
