description: “Nuea Pad Nam Man Hoi” ( เนื้อผัดน้ำมันหอย ) is a simple wok dish where marinated beef is stir-fried and finished with a mixture of oyster sauce, water, salt and white pepper. Often Nuea Pad Nam Man Hoi is also mixed with crisp vegetables. The dish is sometimes simply called “Nuea Nam Man Hoi” ( เนื้อน้ำมันหอย ).
thaiName: เนื้อผัดน้ำมันหอย

description: “Nuea Pad Normai” ( เนื้อผัดหน่อไม้ ) is a wok dish where beef marinated in soy sauce and pepper is stir-fried together with garlic and bamboo shoots. Holy basil is mixed in at the end.
thaiName: เนื้อผัดหน่อไม้

description: “Nuea Pad Pak Choi” ( เนื้อผัดผักฉ่อย ) is a Thai stir-fry with beef and bok choy. Both ingredients are stir-fried together with garlic and chilis, then deglazed with a mixture of soy sauce, fish sauce, and oyster sauce.
thaiName: เนื้อผัดผักฉ่อย

description: "Nuea Pad Phed Krachai" ( เนื้อผัดเผ็ดกระชาย ) is a stir-fry in which beef is cooked with red curry paste and strips of fingerroot. Fresh vegetables such as snake beans or baby corn are often added. The dish is also found under the shortened name “Nuea Pad Krachai” ( เนื้อผัดกระชาย ) or with reversed word order as “Pad Phed Nuea Krachai” ( ผัดเผ็ดเนื้อกระชาย ).
thaiName: เนื้อผัดเผ็ดกระชาย

transcription: Nuea Pad Phed Prik Thai On
summary: Spicy Stir-Fried Beef with Green Pepper
description: “Nuea Pad Phed Prik Thai On” ( เนื้อผัดเผ็ดพริกไทยอ่อน ) is a Thai stir-fry dish where beef is stir-fried together with bamboo shoots, galangal and fresh green pepper in red curry paste. The dish is typically served with jasmine rice. Depending on the recipe, some coconut milk can also be used during preparation.
alternativeNames: Nüa Pad Phet Prik Thai On
Neua Pad Ped Prik Thai On
Nua Pad Phed Prik Thai On
Neua Phad Ped Prik Thai On
thaiName: เนื้อผัดเผ็ดพริกไทยอ่อน

description: “Nuea Pad Prik Sod” ( เนื้อผัดพริกสด ) is a wok dish where beef is stir-fried together with somewhat milder green and red chili peppers. Alternatively, bell peppers can be used. The dish can also be found under the name “Nuea Pad Prik On” ( เนื้อผัดพริกอ่อน ).
thaiName: เนื้อผัดพริกสด

description: “Nuea Pad Prik Thai Dam” ( เนื้อผัดพริกไทยดำ ) is a Thai stir-fry dish in which beef is stir-fried with vegetables, spring onions, garlic, and coarsely crushed black peppercorns. The whole dish is deglazed with a sauce made from oyster sauce, fish sauce, light soy sauce, and palm sugar. The dish is typically served with jasmine rice. The dish can also be found under the shortened name “Nuea Pad Prik” ( เนื้อผัดพริก ).
thaiName: เนื้อผัดพริกไทยดำ

description: “Nuea Pad Thakrai” ( เนื้อผัดตะไคร้ ) is a stir-fry dish where beef is stir-fried with a simple paste made from lemongrass, garlic and chilis. The whole dish is seasoned with a mixture of soy sauce, fish sauce and oyster sauce and then garnished with kaffir lime leaves and chilis.
thaiName: เนื้อผัดตะไคร้

description: “Nuea Ping” ( เนื้อปิ้ง ) are skewers with beef that are grilled over charcoal or open fire. The meat is first marinated in a marinade made from soy sauce, garlic and other spices. These skewers are very popular as a snack and are usually served with a spicy sauce and sticky rice.
thaiName: เนื้อปิ้ง

description:
“Nuea Satay” ( เนื้อสะเต๊ะ ) are grilled beef skewers. This snack is served, like the better-known variations made from pork or chicken, usually with a peanut dip and “Ajaad”.
There is also a variation that originates from the court of King Rama V, but has its origins in Indonesian Java. The skewers are marinated with spices and crushed peanuts and served with a sweet and sour chili sauce. This can be found for example in the book “Bangkok” by
thaiName: เนื้อสะเต๊ะ

description: “Nuea toon ( เนื้อตุ๋น ) is a Thai stew in which beef is cooked with spices such as cinnamon, star anise and coriander seeds for several hours until it is very tender. Nuea toon can be served with rice or rice noodles.
thaiName: เนื้อตุ๋น

description: “Ob Gai Asii Pian” ( อบไก่อสีเปียน ) is an aromatic chicken curry from the northern Thai province of Mae Hong Son. In the preparation of this Shan curry, the meat is first braised covered (“Ob”), which concentrates the flavors, and then continued cooking with the lid open until the oil returns (“Asii Pian”), creating an aromatic mixture of fat and herbs.
thaiName: อบไก่อสีเปียน

description:
“Or Lam” ( เอาะหลาม ) is originally a stew that is typical of the Laotian provinces of Luang Prabang and Sayaburi. However, due to the fact that most of the inhabitants of Isaan in north-eastern Thailand have Laotian roots, Or Lam is also widespread in this Thai region. This stew is also known in the neighboring areas to Laos in northern Thailand.
The stew is made from a paste of crushed Thai eggplants, chilis, garlic, shallots and lemongrass and thickened with sticky rice or khao khua. The meat used is mainly buffalo meat or buffalo skin, but beef and pork or pork belly are also used.
Other Thai eggplants, bamboo shoots or mushrooms are often used as additional ingredients. Another important ingredient is “mai sakhaan”, a spice wood that is also known as “pepperwood” in English.
An Or Lam is further rounded off with Plaa Ra and fresh herbs such as dill, coriander, lemon basil or pumpkin leaves. Closely related to Or Lam is the north-east Thai version of Gaeng Om, which is, however, less thickened.
The name of this dish is made up of the words “Or” and “Lam”. “Or” ( เอาะ ) means thick and refers to the creamy consistency and “Lam” ( หลาม ) refers to the original method of preparation, in which this stew was cooked in thick bamboo tubes over an open fire.
thaiName: เอาะหลาม

description:
“Or Lam Moo” ( เอาะหลามหมู ) is originally a Laotian stew, but is also widespread in the north-eastern Thai cuisine of Isaan . The broth is thickened with crushed Thai eggplants and sticky rice and contains pork or pork belly.
The base of the broth is a paste made from Thai eggplants, chilies, garlic, shallots and lemongrass. Vegetables, bamboo shoots or mushrooms and “mai sakhaan”, an aromatic Laotian spice, are often added. Or lam is served garnished with fresh herbs such as dill or coriander. It is typically served with sticky rice.
thaiName: เอาะหลามหมู

description:
“Or Lam Nuea” ( เอาะหลามเนื้อ ) is actually a Laotian stew, but it is also widespread in Isaan in north-eastern Thailand. It is a beef soup thickened with crushed Thai eggplants and sticky rice.
It is prepared using a paste made from Thai eggplants, chilis, garlic, shallots and lemongrass. Other ingredients such as vegetables, bamboo shoots or mushrooms and “mai sakhaan”, a Laotian type of spice, are usually added. Or lam is then garnished with fresh herbs such as dill or coriander.
The dish is also known in Isaan as “Or Lam Seen” ( เอาะหลามเซิน ). Here, the Laotian term “Seen” (เซิน) is used for the beef.
thaiName: เอาะหลามเนื้อ

description:
"Pa Thong Go" ( ปาท่องโก๋ ) is a popular Thai variation of the traditional Chinese pastry “Youtiao” (油條). These strips of dough fried in hot oil are typically served as breakfast, often accompanied by sweetened coconut milk or soya milk.
The term “Pa Thong Go” does not originate from the Youtiao, but comes from the Chinese term for a rice cake called “Bái Tángguǒ” (白糖粿). Street vendors in Thailand used to offer both this cake and youtiao, calling out both names.
Over time, the Thai public apparently assumed that the name Pa Thong Go belonged to the deep-fried sticks. As the actual rice cake found little favour , it gradually disappeared from the market - what remained was the name that is still used for youtiao in Thailand today.
thaiName: ปาท่องโก๋

description: "Pad Ba Mee" ( ผัดบะหมี่ ) is a stir-fried dish with egg noodles. For preparation, garlic is briefly fried, then mixed with the noodles and seasoned with fish sauce, oyster sauce, and a little palm sugar. Typical additional ingredients include mung bean sprouts and spring onions, but the dish can be prepared with almost any vegetables and different meats. It is also known as “Ba Mee Pad” ( บะหมี่ผัด ), “Pad Mee” ( ผัดหมี่ ), or “Pad Mee Lueang” ( ผัดหมี่เหลือง ).
thaiName: ผัดบะหมี่

summary: Fried noodles with red marinated meat
description: “Pad Ba Mee Moo Daeng” ( ผัดบะหมี่หมูแดง ) is the fried version of the Thai noodle dish “Ba Mie Mhu Daeng”. It consists of fried yellow egg noodles that are stir-fried with red-marinated pork (mhu daeng), vegetables, eggs and a sweet red sauce . The dish can also be found under the shortened name “Pad Mee Moo Daeng” ( ผัดหมี่หมูแดง ).
thaiName: ผัดบะหมี่หมูแดง

description: Pad Buap Sai Khai" ( ผัดบวบใส่ไข่ ) is sliced angled gourd fried together with whisked eggs . This combination is a popular breakfast in Thailand. The dish is also known under the longer name “Pad Buap Liam Sai Khai” ( ผัดบวบเหลี่ยมใส่ไข่ ) or as “Pad Mara Wan Sai Khai” ( ผัดมะระหวานใส่ไข่ ).
thaiName: ผัดบวบใส่ไข่

description:
“Pad Cha Gai” ( ผัดฉ่าไก่ ) is a stir-fried dish with chicken and various vegetables. What makes it special is that it is based on a spicy paste made from chillies, garlic and galangal. The dish is also seasoned with fingerroot, kaffir lime leaves, Thai basil and fresh green pepper, as well as fish sauce, soy sauce and rice wine.
The name component “Cha” is an onomatopoeic description of the sound made when the ingredients are fried at high heat. The first part “Pad” means “to fry” and the last part “Gai” stands for “chicken”. The whole thing can therefore be translated as “sizzling fried chicken”. The dish is also known by the reverse name “Gai Pad Cha” ( ไก่ผัดฉ่า ).
thaiName: ผัดฉ่าไก่

description:
“Pad Cha Plaa” ( ผัดฉ่าปลา ) is a wok dish with fish and various vegetables based on a spicy paste made from chilies, garlic and galangal. It is seasoned with Chinese keys, kaffir lime leaves, Thai basil and fresh green pepper as well as fish sauce, soy sauce and rice wine.
The name component “Cha” onomatopoetically describes the sound the dish makes when frying. The first part “Pad” means “stir-fry” and at the end is “Plaa” for “fish”. The whole thing can thus be translated as “Sizzling stir-fried fish”.
The dish is also known under the reversed name “Plaa Pad Cha” ( ปลาผัดฉ่า ). According to the book Thailand: The Cookbook, there is also a variant from Northern Thailand that uses a simpler paste but more vegetables.
thaiName: ผัดฉ่าปลา

description:
“Pad Cha Talee” ( ผัดฉ่าทะเล ) is a wok dish with seafood based on a spicy paste made from garlic, chilis and galangal. The dish is seasoned with fingerroot, Thai basil, kaffir lime leaves and fresh green peppercorns as well as fish sauce, soy sauce and rice wine.
The second part of the name “Cha” describes the sound that the dish makes when stir-frying. Before it stands “Pad”, which means “stir-fry” and at the end “Talee” for the seafood. The whole thing can thus be translated as “Sizzling stir-fried seafood”.
thaiName: ผัดฉ่าทะเล

transcription: Pad Dok Ga Prau Moo Sap
summary: Minced Pork with Holy Basil Flowers
description: “Pad Dok Ga Prau Moo Sap” ( ผัดดอกกะเพราหมูสับ ) is a variation of the well-known dish “Pad Ga Prau” in which minced pork is stir-fried together with holy basil flowers.
alternativeNames: Pad Dok Ka Prau Moo Sap
Pad Dok Kra Pow Moo Sap
Pad Dok Gra Pow Moo Sap
Pad Dok Gra Pow Moo Sup
thaiName: ผัดดอกกะเพราหมูสับ

description: “Pad Dok Kachorn Moo” ( ผัดดอกขจรหมู ) is a stir-fry dish where pork is stir-fried together with Tonkin flowers. The whole dish is seasoned with garlic, oyster sauce, soy sauce and white pepper.
thaiName: ผัดดอกขจรหมู

summary: Minced Pork with Yellow Sesbania Flowers
description: “Pad Dok Seno Moo Sap” ( ผัดดอกโสนหมูสับ ) is a simple wok dish where minced pork and yellow sesbania flowers are stir-fried together with garlic and Thai chilis. The whole dish is then seasoned with a mixture of oyster sauce, soy sauce, fish sauce and palm sugar.
thaiName: ผัดดอกโสนหมูสับ

description: "Pad Fak Thong" ( ผัดฟักทอง ) is stir-fried pumpkin that is stir-fried with ginger, galangal, lemongrass, garlic, chilis and soy sauce. The whole dish is then mixed with scrambled eggs and horapa basil.
thaiName: ผัดฟักทอง

summary: Stir-Fried Pork with Pumpkin and Egg
description: “Pad Fak Thong Moo” ( ผัดฟักทองหมู ) is pork that is stir-fried together with pre-cooked pumpkin. Both are seasoned with garlic, fish sauce and soy sauce and finally mixed with scrambled eggs and horapa basil.
thaiName: ผัดฟักทองหมู

description: “Pad Ga Prau” ( ผัดกะเพรา ) is the name given to wok dishes prepared with chopped or minced meat (usually chicken, beef or pork), fresh Ga Prau basil and a paste made from garlic and chili peppers. These ingredients are sautéed and deglazed with a sauce made from fish sauce, soy sauce and oyster sauce. Pad Ga Prau is often served with a fried egg.
thaiName: ผัดกะเพรา

description: “Pad Ga Prau Gai” ( ผัดกะเพราไก่ ) is a wok dish in which chopped chicken is sautéed in a simple paste made from chilies and garlic. The whole thing is then deglazed with a mixture of different sauces and mixed with holy basil (Bai Ga Prau).
thaiName: ผัดกะเพราไก่

description: “Pad Ga Prau Goong” ( ผัดกะเพรากุ้ง ) are prawns that are stir-fried with a simple paste of garlic and chilies. The prawns are then seasoned with fish sauce and soy sauce and mixed with Holy Basil.
thaiName: ผัดกะเพรากุ้ง

description:
“Pad Ga Prau Hed” ( ผัดกะเพราเห็ด ) is a stir-fry dish where mushrooms are stir-fried together with garlic and chilis. The whole dish is then deglazed with fish sauce and soy sauce. At the end, holy basil (Bai Ga Prau) is mixed in, which gives the whole dish its name and special flavor.
Depending on the type of mushrooms, the dish can also be named more explicitly, such as Pad Ga Prau Hed Bpu Than. The dish can also be found under the reversed name “Hed Pad Ga Prau” ( เห็ดผัดกะเพรา ).
thaiName: ผัดกะเพราเห็ด

transcription: Pad Ga Prau Hed Bpu Than
description: In “Pad Ga Prau Hed Phu Than” ( ผัดกะเพราเห็ดภูฐาน ), a stir-fry dish with holy basil, abalone mushrooms are used according to the recipe, which are called “Hed Phu Than” in Thai. Since these are difficult to obtain here, oyster mushrooms can be used instead.
alternativeNames: Pad Kra Pao Hed Bpu Than
thaiName: ผัดกะเพราเห็ดภูฐาน

description: “Pad Ga Prau Look Chin” ( ผัดกะเพราลูกชิ้น ) is a variation of the classic Pad Ga Prau in which meatballs (Look Chin) are the main ingredient. The meatballs are stir-fried in a wok with a paste made from garlic and chili peppers, then deglazed with fish sauce, soy sauce and Golden Mountain Sauce. Fresh Ga Prau basil gives the dish its characteristic aroma. Depending on the recipe, the meatballs are also stir-fried together with minced meat.
thaiName: ผัดกะเพราลูกชิ้น

description: “Pad Ga Prau Moo” ( ผัดกะเพราหมู ) is a stir-fried dish with pork and holy basil. The pork is sautéed with a paste made from crushed garlic and chili peppers before being deglazed with a mixture of oyster sauce, fish sauce and soy sauce. The basil leaves (bai ga prau) are added at the end . Sometimes green beans or other vegetables are also mixed in. The dish is served with a fried egg and jasmine rice.
thaiName: ผัดกะเพราหมู

summary: Crispy pork belly with holy basil
description: Pad Ga Prau Moo Grob" ( ผัดกะเพราหมูกรอบ ) is crispy deep-fried pork belly, which is fried together with a simple paste of garlic and chilies. Everything is then deglazed with a mixture of different soy sauces and mixed with holy basil before serving.
thaiName: ผัดกะเพราหมูกรอบ

description: "Pad Ga Prau Moo Sap" ( ผัดกะเพราหมูสับ ) is a variation of Pad Kra Pao, in which minced pork is fried with the usual mixture of crushed garlic and chilis and seasoned with various sauces and holy basil. The “Pad Ga Prau Moo Sap” is also usually served with a fried egg or “Khai Doa”
thaiName: ผัดกะเพราหมูสับ

transcription: Pad Ga Prau Moo Sap Sai Kha Min
summary: Minced meat with turmeric and holy basil
description: “Pad Ga Prau Moo Sap Sai Kha Min” ( ผัดกะเพราหมูสับใส่ขมิ้น ) is a variation of Pad Kra Pao, which is prepared with minced pork. However, in addition to the usual ingredients for Pad Ga Prau, turmeric powder is also mixed in here, which gives the dish a strong yellow colour.
alternativeNames: Pad Gaprao Moo Sap Sai Kamin
Pad Kra Pao Moo Sap Sai Kamin
Pad Krapao Moo Sap Sai Kamin
Phat Kaphrao Moo Sap Sai Kamin
Phat Gra Phrao Muu Sap Sai Khai Min
thaiName: ผัดกะเพราหมูสับใส่ขมิ้น

description: “Pad Ga Prau Moo Yor” ( ผัดกะเพราหมูยอ ) is a variation of Pad Ga Prau that uses sliced Vietnamese sausage instead of meat. This sausage is also fried with a paste of garlic and chilies and then deglazed with a mixture of different sauces before the holy basil is added.
thaiName: ผัดกะเพราหมูยอ

description: "Pad Ga Prau Nuea" ( ผัดกะเพราเนื้อ ) is a stir-fried dish with beef and holy basil. The beef is sautéed with crushed garlic and Thai chilies and then deglazed with a mixture of oyster sauce, fish sauce and soy sauce. Finally, leaves of holy basil (Bai Ga Prau) are added. Depending on the recipe, snake beans or other vegetables can also be added to the meat. The dish is typically served with a fried egg and jasmine rice.
thaiName: ผัดกะเพราเนื้อ

description: “Pad Ga Prau Plaa” ( ผัดกะเพราปลา ) is chopped or minced fish that is stir-fried together with crushed garlic and chilis. It is then deglazed with a mixture of fish sauce, soy sauce and Golden Mountain Sauce and mixed with holy basil.
thaiName: ผัดกะเพราปลา

description: “Pad Ga Prau Plaa Muek” ( ผัดกะเพราปลาหมึก ) consists of squid that is stir-fried together with crushed garlic and chilis. Afterwards, the whole dish is deglazed with a mixture of various sauces and mixed with “Bai Ga Prau” (holy basil).
thaiName: ผัดกะเพราปลาหมึก

summary: Platter with different types of Pad Ga Prau
description: "Pad Ga Prau Thad" ( ผัดกะเพราถาด ) is the name given to a large platter on which various types of Pad Ga Prau and the obligatory fried eggs are served together. Sometimes the accompanying jasmine rice is also served in the middle of the platter.
thaiName: ผัดกะเพราถาด

summary: Stir-Fried Free-Range Chicken with Thai Eggplant
description: This simple wok dish with chicken and Thai eggplant is called “Pad Gai Baan Makuea Lueang” ( ผัดไก่บ้านมะเขือเหลือง ) and is very quick to prepare. The dish can also be found under the name “Pad Makuea Prau Sai Gai” ( ผัดมะเขือเปราะใส่ไก่ ).
alternativeNames: Pad Gai Baan Ma kuea Lueang
Phat Kai Baan Ma Kuea Lueang
thaiName: ผัดไก่บ้านมะเขือเหลือง

description: "Pad Galam Plee Gai" ( ผัดกะหล่ำปลีไก่ ) is a Thai stir-fry in which cabbage is stir-fried together with chicken, garlic, and chilis. The dish is then deglazed with fish sauce, oyster sauce, and soy sauce. This dish is also known as “Galam Plee Pad Gai” ( กะหล่ำปลีผัดไก่ ).
thaiName: ผัดกะหล่ำปลีไก่

description: “Pad Galam Plee Moo Sap” ( ผัดกะหล่ำปลีหมูสับ ) is a simple stir-fry in which cabbage, such as napa cabbage or bok choy, is stir-fried together with garlic, chilis, and minced pork. The dish is then deglazed with a mixture of soy sauce, oyster sauce, and fish sauce.
thaiName: ผัดกะหล่ำปลีหมูสับ

description: “Pad Galam Plee Nam Plaa” ( ผัดกะหล่ำปลีน้ำปลา ) is probably one of the simplest Thai stir-fry dishes. It consists of napa cabbage or regular cabbage simply stir-fried with garlic and fish sauce, that’s it! The recipe can also be found under the name “Galam Plee Thod Nam Plaa” ( กะหล่ำปลีทอดน้ำปลา ).
thaiName: ผัดกะหล่ำปลีน้ำปลา

description: “Pad Gunchiang Hed” ( ผัดกุนเชียงเห็ด ) is a wok dish in which Thai gunchiang is stir-fried together with mushrooms and some garlic. The dish is seasoned with a mixture of oyster sauce, soy sauce and palm sugar. If specific mushrooms are used, their name can be appended to the name of the dish.
thaiName: ผัดกุนเชียงเห็ด

transcription: Pad Hed Fang Nam Man Hoi
description: In “Pad Hed Fang Nam Man Hoi” ( ผัดเห็ดฟางน้ำมันหอย ), pork is stir-fried together with straw mushrooms and a sauce mixture with oyster sauce.
alternativeNames: Phat Hed Fang Nam Man Hoi
Phat Hed Fang Nam Man Hoy
thaiName: ผัดเห็ดฟางน้ำมันหอย

transcription: Pad Hed Hom Nam Man Hoi
summary: Stir-fried Shiitake Mushrooms in Oyster Sauce
description: “Pad Hed Hom Nam Man Hoi” ( ผัดเห็ดหอมน้ำมันหอย ) are fried shiitake mushrooms. They are first sautéed with garlic and then deglazed with a mixture of oyster sauce, soy sauce and a little chicken stock. The dish is also known under the reversed names “Hed Hom Pad Nam Man Hoi” ( เห็ดหอมผัดน้ำมันหอย ) or “Hed Hom Sot Pad Nam Man Hoi” ( เห็ดหอมสดผัดน้ำมันหอย ).
alternativeNames: Pad Het Hom Nam Man Hoi
Hed Hom Pad Nam Man Hoi
Hed Hom Sot Pad Nam Man Hoi
thaiName: ผัดเห็ดหอมน้ำมันหอย

transcription: Pad Hed Khao Phot On Goong
summary: Stir-Fried Prawns with Mushrooms and Baby Corn
description: In this simple stir-fry dish called “Pad Hed Khao Phot On Goong” ( ผัดเห็ดข้าวโพดอ่อนกุ้ง ), mushrooms are stir-fried together with prawns and baby corn. In “Thailand: The Cookbook,” the dish is listed as “Pad Hed Khon Khao Phot On Goong” ( ผัดเห็ดโคนข้าวโพดอ่อนกุ้ง ), meaning a specific type of mushroom is used in that recipe.
alternativeNames: Pad Hed Khao Phot On Goong
Phat Het Khao Phot On Goong
Pad Hed Khon Khao Phot On Gung
thaiName: ผัดเห็ดข้าวโพดอ่อนกุ้ง

summary: Fried King Oyster Mushrooms with Prawns
description: Pad Hed Orinji Goong ( ผัดเห็ดออรินจิกุ้ง ) is a wok-fried dish with king oyster mushrooms and prawns. The two ingredients are sautéed together with spring onions and garlic as well as a mixture of palm sugar, soy sauce and oyster sauce.
thaiName: ผัดเห็ดออรินจิกุ้ง

summary: Stir-Fried King Oyster Mushrooms with Minced Pork
description: “Pad Hed Orinji Moo Sap” ( ผัดเห็ดออรินจิหมูสับ ) is a stir-fry dish with king oyster mushrooms and minced pork. The mushrooms and meat are stir-fried together with chilis, garlic, and spring onions in a mixture of soy sauce, fish sauce, oyster sauce, and palm sugar.
thaiName: ผัดเห็ดออรินจิหมูสับ

description: “Pad Hed Ruam” ( ผัดเห็ดรวม ) is a stir-fry dish featuring various types of mushrooms. The mushrooms are fried with garlic and chilies, then deglazed with a mixture of soy sauce, oyster sauce, and fish sauce. This dish is also known as “Pad Hed” ( ผัดเห็ด ).
thaiName: ผัดเห็ดรวม

description:
“Pad Hoi Ga Phong” ( ผัดหอยกะพง ) consists of green mussels that are stir-fried together with garlic and soy sauce and then mixed with Thai Horapa basil. This wok dish is also found under the more general name “Pad Hoi Malaeng Poo” ( ผัดหอยแมลงภู่ ).
In the English edition of the book “Thailand - The Cookbook” the recipe refers to “Small Horse Mussels”, while in the German edition they are simply called “Miesmuscheln”. The “Small Horse Mussel” is called “Große Miesmuschel” or “Pferdemuschel” in German, which is a particularly large mussel species from the mussel family.
thaiName: ผัดหอยกะพง

description: “Pad Horapa Gai” ( ผัดโหระพาไก่ ) is a thai dish where chicken is stir-fried with Thai basil. The dish is prepared with a simple paste of garlic and chilis and is seasoned with a mixture of fish sauce and dark soy sauce. It is also known by the reversed name “Gai Pad Horapa” ( ไก่ผัดโหระพา ).
thaiName: ผัดโหระพาไก่

description: “Pad Horapa Moo” ( ผัดโหระพาหมู ) is a Thai stir-fry dish where pork is fried with Thai basil. The dish is based on a simple paste of garlic and chilis and deglazed with a mixture of fish sauce and dark soy sauce. It can also be found under the reversed name “Moo Pad Horapa” ( หมูผัดโหระพา ).
thaiName: ผัดโหระพาหมู

summary: Crispy Pork Belly with Thai Basil
description: “Pad Horapa Moo Grob” ( ผัดโหระพาหมูกรอบ ) is crispy pork belly that is stir-fried in a simple paste of chilis and garlic. The whole dish is then deglazed with a mixture of fish sauce and various soy sauces before Thai basil is folded into the dish.
thaiName: ผัดโหระพาหมูกรอบ

description: “Pad Horapa Moo Sap” ( ผัดโหระพาหมูสับ ) is a stir-fry dish where minced pork and Thai basil are stir-fried together with a simple paste of garlic and Thai chilis. The whole dish is deglazed with a mixture of fish sauce and soy sauce and served with rice. The dish is sometimes called “Moo Sap Pad Horapa” ( หมูสับผัดโหระพา ) in a different word order. Like the better-known Pad Ga Prau Moo Sap, a fried egg goes perfectly with this dish.
thaiName: ผัดโหระพาหมูสับ

summary: Stir-Fried Stink Beans with Shrimp Paste
description: “Pad Kapi Sator” ( ผัดกะปิสะตอ ) is a Southern Thai stir-fry dish where meat or prawns are stir-fried together with stink beans in a large amount of shrimp paste. In Southern Thailand, the dish is also called “Pad Khoey Sator” ( ผัดเคยสะตอ ).
thaiName: ผัดกะปิสะตอ

description:
"Pad Kee Mao" ( ผัดขี้เมา ) refers to various wok dishes in which meat or seafood is sautéed with garlic, various types of chili, green pepper and kraichai. The whole thing is deglazed with a mixture of oyster sauce, fish sauce and Chinese cooking wine and garnished with holy basil. Sometimes various vegetables, such as baby corn on the cob or snake beans are added to the main ingredient.
The name part “Khi Mao” can be translated as “drunk”, ‘intoxicated’ or “drunkard”. It is not really clear where the name comes from. However, there are various theories according to which the dish is so spicy that it chases away any “hangover”, the inventor of the dish was very drunk and fried everything he found together or that the dish is so aromatic that it intoxicates you.
Originally, these wok dishes were plated dishes served with rice. Later, variations in which the rice was replaced with rice noodles and these noodles were also fried became increasingly popular. Today, the dish is almost exclusively served as a noodle dish, often referred to as “drunken noodles”.
thaiName: ผัดขี้เมา

transcription: Pad Kee Mao Gai Sai Normai
description: “Pad Kee Mao Gai Sai Normai ( ผัดขี้เมาไก่ใส่หน่อไม้ ) is a wok dish with chicken and bamboo shoots. Both are sautéed with a spicy paste made from quite a lot of chilies, shallots and garlic and deglazed with a mixture of fish sauce, oyster sauce and soy sauce . At the end, leaves of holy basil are folded in. The finished dish is served with rice or rice noodles.
alternativeNames: Pad Khi Mao Gai Sai Normai
Pad Ki Mao Gai Sai Normai
Phat Kee Mao Kai Sai Normai
thaiName: ผัดขี้เมาไก่ใส่หน่อไม้

description: “Pad Kee Mao Goong” ( ผัดขี้เมากุ้ง ) is a Thai stir-fry dish in which prawns are sautéed with garlic, various types of chili, fresh green pepper and chinese keys. It is seasoned with a mixture of oyster sauce, fish sauce and Chinese cooking wine before being garnished with holy basil. This dish is typically served with jasmine rice.
thaiName: ผัดขี้เมากุ้ง

description: “Pad Makuea Prau Sai Moo” ( ผัดมะเขือเปราะใส่หมู ) is a Thai stir-fry dish where pork, Thai eggplant and chilis are stir-fried in red curry paste. The dish is seasoned with fish sauce and palm sugar and garnished with Thai basil. The dish can also be found under the name “Gaeng Moo Makuea” ( แกงหมูมะเขือ ).
thaiName: ผัดมะเขือเปราะใส่หมู

description: “Pad Makuea Yao” ( ผัดมะเขือยาว ) is a stir-fry dish with eggplant and minced meat. As a substitute for the long Thai eggplants, slender Japanese eggplants work very well.
thaiName: ผัดมะเขือยาว

description: “Pad Mama Gai” ( ผัดมาม่าไก่ ) is stir-fried instant noodles with chicken and vegetables. This simple wok dish is seasoned with garlic, white pepper, oyster sauce, fish sauce, and light soy sauce. Depending on the recipe, the seasoning packet from the instant noodles is also used. The dish can also be found under the reversed name “Mama Pad Gai” ( มาม่าผัดไก่ ).
thaiName: ผัดมาม่าไก่

description: “Pad Mama Goong” ( ผัดมาม่ากุ้ง ) is a simple wok dish where Mama instant noodles are stir-fried together with prawns. Optionally, various vegetables, eggs, or mushrooms are also used. For seasoning, garlic, fish sauce, soy sauce, and oyster sauce are employed. The second part of the name comes from Thailand’s most famous instant noodle manufacturer “Mama”, “Pad” is a wok dish, and “Goong” means prawns.
thaiName: ผัดมาม่ากุ้ง

summary: Fried Instant Noodles in an Omelette
description: Pad Mama Hor Khai" ( ผัดมาม่าห่อไข่ ) is a simple stir-fry dish, in which mama instant noodles are fried together with meat or seafood and vegetables and served in an omelette. The noodles are seasoned with garlic and a mixture of oyster sauce, fish sauce and soy sauce.
thaiName: ผัดมาม่าห่อไข่

description: “Pad Mama Moo” ( ผัดมาม่าหมู ) is a simple wok dish in which Mama instant noodles are stir-fried together with pork, vegetables and eggs in a wok.
thaiName: ผัดมาม่าหมู

description: The “Pad Mee Hok Gian” ( ผัดหมี่ฮกเกี้ยน ), or simply “Mee Hok Gian” ( หมี่ฮกเกี้ยน ), is a southern Thai noodle dish where mee noodles are stir-fried together with pork, seafood, and Chinese cabbage.
thaiName: ผัดหมี่ฮกเกี้ยน

description:
“Pad Mee Khorat” ( ผัดหมี่โคราช ) is a noodle dish from Isaan in which noodles are fried together with meat or prawns and vegetables with various spices and chilli powder. It originates from the city of Nakhon Ratchasima, which is usually simply called “Khorat”. Compared to many other Thai noodle dishes, it is characterised by a certain spiciness.
Rezepte
thaiName: ผัดหมี่โคราช

summary: Stir-Fried Noodles in Coconut Milk with Shrimp
description: "Pad Mee Phak Phanang" ( ผัดหมี่ปากพนัง ) is stir-fried noodles as they are prepared in the “Phak Phanang” district in the southern Thai province of Nakhon Si Thammarat. The noodles are mixed with a sauce made from shallots, chilis, coconut milk, shrimp paste, tamarind and palm sugar. It is usually served with shrimp or other seafood.
thaiName: ผัดหมี่ปากพนัง

summary: Stir-Fried Minced Pork With Thai Eggplant
description: “Pad Moo Sap Makuea Prau” ( ผัดหมูสับมะเขือเปราะ ) is a wok dish where minced pork and Thai eggplant are stir-fried with garlic and Thai chilis. The whole dish is deglazed with a mixture of oyster sauce, fish sauce and soy sauce and seasoned with some Thai basil.
alternativeNames: Phat Moo Sap Ma Kua Prau
thaiName: ผัดหมูสับมะเขือเปราะ

description: “Pad Normai Farang Goong” ( ผัดหน่อไม้ฝรั่งกุ้ง ) is a stir-fry dish with green asparagus and prawns. Both are stir-fried together with garlic and seasoned with a mixture of soy sauce, fish sauce and oyster sauce. Sometimes other vegetables such as baby corn are added to the two main ingredients.
thaiName: ผัดหน่อไม้ฝรั่งกุ้ง

description: "Pad Pak Bung Fai Daeng" ( ผัดผักบุ้งไฟแดง ) is a wok dish where water spinach is stir-fried at very high heat together with garlic, chilis, yellow bean paste and a mixture of soy, fish and oyster sauces. The name means something like “water spinach stir-fried in red flame”. On English-language menus it is often found as “Fried Morning Glory”.
thaiName: ผัดผักบุ้งไฟแดง

transcription: Pad Pak Bung Kapi Sai Moo Sap
summary: Water Spinach with Shrimp Paste and Minced Pork
description: “Pad Pak Bung Kapi Sai Moo Sap” ( ผัดผักบุ้งกะปิใส่หมูสับ ) is a wok dish where water spinach is stir-fried together with minced pork and a paste made from garlic, chilis and shrimp paste.
alternativeNames: Pad Pak Bung Kapi Sai Moo Sap
Phat Pak Boong Kapi Sai Moo Sap
Pak Boong Phat Gabpi Sai Muu Sap
thaiName: ผัดผักบุ้งกะปิใส่หมูสับ

transcription: Pad Pak Bung Nam Man Hoi
summary: Stir-Fried Water Spinach With Oyster Sauce
description: “Pad Pak Bung Nam Man Hoi” ( ผัดผักบุ้งน้ำมันหอย ) is a fairly simple wok dish. Here, water spinach is stir-fried with garlic and then finished with a mixture of oyster sauce and soy sauce. There is also a longer name for this dish: “Pak Bung Ya Leng Nam Man Hoi” ( ผักบุ้งยเลงน้ำมันหอย ).
alternativeNames: Phad Phak Bung Naam Man Hoi
Pak Bung Ya Leng Nam Man Hoi
thaiName: ผัดผักบุ้งน้ำมันหอย

summary: Bok Choy with Yellow Bean Paste
description: “Pad Pak Choi Tao Jiaw” ( ผัดผักฉ่อยเต้าเจี้ยว ) is a simple wok dish with bok choy. The bok choy is stir-fried together with garlic, Thai chilis and yellow bean paste. The dish is also known under the name “Pak Kwang Tung Pad Tao Jiaw” ( ผักกวางตุ้งผัดเต้าเจี้ยว ).
alternativeNames: Pak Kwang Tung Pad Tao Djiau
Phak Kwang Toong Phat Tao Jiao
thaiName: ผัดผักฉ่อยเต้าเจี้ยว

description: “Pad Pak Dong Moo Sap” ( ผัดผักดองหมูสับ ) is a simple wok dish from northern Thailand. Here, minced meat and pickled leafy vegetables are stir-fried together with garlic and chilis and then deglazed with a mixture of soy sauce, fish sauce and oyster sauce. The dish can also be found under the name “Moo Sap Pad Gap Pak Dong” ( หมูสับผัดกับผักดอง ).
alternativeNames: Moo Sap Pad Gap Pak Dong
Muu Sap Phat Kap Phak Dawng
thaiName: ผัดผักดองหมูสับ

description: “Pad Pak Kanaa Gai” ( ผัดผักคะน้าไก่ ) is a simple wok dish with chicken and Chinese broccoli. Both are stir-fried with garlic and chilis and then finished with a mixture of oyster sauce, soy sauce, and fish sauce. There are also variations of this dish where the meat is minced, which is then called “Pad Pak Kanaa Gai Sap” ( ผัดผักคะน้าไก่สับ ).
thaiName: ผัดผักคะน้าไก่

description: “Pad Pak Kanaa Moo Grob” ( ผัดผักคะน้าหมูกรอบ ) is a stir-fry dish in which crispy pork belly is stir-fried together with Chinese broccoli. The name of the dish is often shortened to “Pad Kanaa Moo Grob” ( ผัดคะน้าหมูกรอบ ) or even “Kanaa Moo Grob” ( คะน้าหมูกรอบ ).
thaiName: ผัดผักคะน้าหมูกรอบ

summary: Stir-Fried Chinese Broccoli with Salted Fish
description:
“Pad Pak Kanaa Plaa Khem” ( ผัดผักคะน้าปลาเค็ม ) is a quick dish with Chinese broccoli. It is stir-fried together with dried fish, chilis and fried garlic. The name of the dish is often shortened to “Pad Kanaa Plaa Khem” ( ผัดคะน้าปลาเค็ม ) or “Kanaa Plaa Khem” ( คะน้าปลาเค็ม ).
In “Thailand: The Cookbook” there is also a simplified variant without chilis, which is called “Pad Jot Kanaa Plaa Khem” ( ผัดยอดคะน้าปลาเค็ม ).
thaiName: ผัดผักคะน้าปลาเค็ม

transcription: Pad Pak Khom Nam Man Hoi
description: “Pad Pak Khom Nam Man Hoi” ( ผัดผักโขมน้ำมันหอย ) is amaranth that is stir-fried with garlic and then deglazed with a mixture of oyster sauce and soy sauce. This dish is sometimes also simply called “Pad Khom Nam Man Hoi” ( ผัดโขมน้ำมันหอย ).
alternativeNames: Phad Phak Khoom Naam Man Hoi
Pak Khom Pad Nan Man Hoi
thaiName: ผัดผักโขมน้ำมันหอย

description: “Pad Pak Khom Tao Hu” ( ผัดผักโขมเต้าหู้ ) is a simple stir-fry where amaranth is stir-fried together with garlic and tofu.
thaiName: ผัดผักโขมเต้าหู้

description: "Pad Pak Ruam Mit" ( ผัดผักรวมมิตร ), or shortened to “Pad Pak Ruam” ( ผัดผักรวม ) or simply “Pad Pak” ( ผัดผัก ), is a simple vegetarian dish in which colourful vegetables are sautéed with garlic and then deglazed with a sauce mixture. This mixture often contains oyster sauce, which means that the dish is no longer truly vegetarian.
thaiName: ผัดผักรวมมิตร

transcription: Pad Pak Tam Lueng Moo Sap
summary: Stir-Fried Ivy Gourd Leaves with Minced Pork
description: In “Pad Pak Tam Lueng Moo Sap” ( ผัดผักตำลึงหมูสับ ) from Southern Thailand, minced pork is stir-fried together with ivy gourd leaves. This dish can also be found under the shortened name “Pad Tam Lueng Moo Sap” ( ผัดตำลึงหมูสับ ). As a substitute for ivy gourd leaves, baby spinach can also be used.
thaiName: ผัดผักตำลึงหมูสับ

description: Pad Panaeng Nuea ( ผัดพะแนงเนื้อ ) is a southern Thai wok dish in which beef is stir-fried together with Panaeng curry paste. Often some vegetables such as pea aubergines are added. The dish is garnished with kaffir lime leaves that have been cut into thin strips.
thaiName: ผัดพะแนงเนื้อ

description: “Pad Phed Gai” ( ผัดเผ็ดไก่ ) is a wok dish with chicken that is stir-fried in red curry paste. In addition to the meat, some vegetables such as snake beans, onions, Thai eggplants, fresh green pepper or bell peppers are usually also used. The dish is typically served with jasmine rice. The dish can also be found under the name “Pad Prik Gai” ( ผัดพริกไก่ ).
thaiName: ผัดเผ็ดไก่

description: This stir-fried “Pad Phed Gai Normai” ( ผัดเผ็ดไก่หน่อไม้ ) with bamboo and chicken is strangely referred to as “Spicy Chicken Curry with Bamboo Shoots” in the book Thailand: The Cookbook, although it is clearly a stir-fried wok dish.
thaiName: ผัดเผ็ดไก่หน่อไม้

transcription: Pad Phed Gai Thua Fak Yao
description: "Pad Phed Gai Thua Fak Yao" ( ผัดเผ็ดไก่ถั่วฝักยาว ) is a stir-fried dish in which chicken and yardlong beans are fried in red curry paste. The dish is also found under the name “Pad Prik Gai Thua Fak Yao” ( ผัดพริกไก่ถั่วฝักยาว ).
alternativeNames: Pad Prik Gai Thua Fak Yao
thaiName: ผัดเผ็ดไก่ถั่วฝักยาว

description: “Pad Phed Moo” ( ผัดเผ็ดหมู ) is a Thai dish with pork that is stir-fried in red curry paste. In addition to the meat, some vegetables such as green beans, yard-long beans, bell peppers, onions or Thai eggplant are usually also used. Pad Phed Moo is typically served with rice.
thaiName: ผัดเผ็ดหมู

summary: Crispy Pork Belly With Red Curry Paste
description: In “Pad Phed Moo Grob” ( ผัดเผ็ดหมูกรอบ ), pork belly is stir-fried until crispy before being mixed with red curry paste and yard-long beans or other vegetables as well as Thai basil. The dish can also be found under the name “Moo Grob Pad Prik Gaeng” ( หมูกรอบผัดพริกแกง ).
thaiName: ผัดเผ็ดหมูกรอบ

summary: Minced Pork Stir-Fried in Curry Paste
description: “Pad Phed Moo Sap” ( ผัดเผ็ดหมูสับ ) is a Thai dish in which minced pork is stir-fried in red curry paste. In addition to the minced meat, green beans or other vegetables are usually also used. The dish is typically served with rice.
thaiName: ผัดเผ็ดหมูสับ

summary: Stir-Fried Minced Pork with Stink Beans
description: “Pad Phed Moo Sap Sator” ( ผัดเผ็ดหมูสับสะตอ ) is a spicy wok dish from Southern Thailand. Minced pork is stir-fried in red curry paste and then mixed with stink beans. The dish is also known as “Pad Prik Moo Sap Sator” ( ผัดพริกหมูสับสะตอ ).
thaiName: ผัดเผ็ดหมูสับสะตอ

summary: Stir-Fried Beef with Red Curry Paste
description: "Pad Phed Nuea" ( ผัดเผ็ดเนื้อ ) is a spicy stir-fry with thinly sliced beef cooked in red curry paste. Typical additional ingredients include baby corn, Thai eggplants, snake beans or mushrooms, as well as kaffir lime leaves.
thaiName: ผัดเผ็ดเนื้อ

transcription: Pad Phed Nuea Thua Fak Yao
description: "Pad Phet Nuea Thua Fak Yao" ( ผัดเผ็ดเนื้อถั่วฝักยาว ) is a simple stir-fried dish in which beef is cooked with yard long beans in red curry paste. It is seasoned with fish sauce and a little palm sugar and is typically served with jasmine rice.
alternativeNames: Pad Phet Nuea Thua Fak Yao
Pad Ped Nua Thua Fak Yao
thaiName: ผัดเผ็ดเนื้อถั่วฝักยาว

description: “Pad Phed Sator Gung” ( ผัดเผ็ดสะตอกุ้ง ) is a southern Thai stir-fry dish made with prawns and sator beans in a spicy curry paste. The dish is also known as “Pad Sator Gung” ( ผัดสะตอกุ้ง ).
thaiName: ผัดเผ็ดสะตอกุ้ง

description: “Pad Plaa Muek Sator” ( ผัดปลาหมึกสะตอ ) is a southern Thai stir-fry where squid is stir-fried together with stink beans in Nam Prik Pao. The dish is then seasoned with palm sugar, some salt, and a generous amount of chilis. The dish can also be found under the name “Plaa Muek Pad Nam Prik Pao” ( ปลาหมึกผัดน้ำพริกเผา ).
alternativeNames: Plaa Muek Pad Nam Prik Pao
thaiName: ผัดปลาหมึกสะตอ

summary: Stir-Fried Pumpkin in Red Curry Paste
description: “Pad Prik Fak Thong” ( ผัดพริกฟักทอง ) is a Thai wok dish in which pumpkin is stir-fried in red curry paste. The pumpkin is pre-cooked and then tossed together with the curry paste in the wok. The dish is seasoned with fish sauce and various types of soy sauce and usually garnished with Thai holy basil.
thaiName: ผัดพริกฟักทอง

summary: Pumpkin and Chicken in Red Curry Paste
description: “Pad Prik Fak Thong Gai” ( ผัดพริกฟักทองไก่ ) is a stir-fry dish where chicken is stir-fried together with pre-cooked pumpkin in red curry paste. The dish is then deglazed with fish sauce and soy sauce and garnished with Thai holy basil.
thaiName: ผัดพริกฟักทองไก่

description: “Pad Prik Khing” ( ผัดพริกขิง ) is always a source of confusion because although “ginger” or in Thai “Khing” ( ขิง ) is in the name, it doesn’t necessarily have to be included. Rather, it is primarily pork stir-fried in a special curry paste. Whether ginger is then added is optional, but it likely corresponds to the original dish.
thaiName: ผัดพริกขิง

description: “Pad Prik Tao Hu Normai” ( ผัดพริกเต้าหู้หน่อไม้ ) is a vegetarian wok dish where tofu is stir-fried together with bamboo shoots and snake beans in red curry paste.
thaiName: ผัดพริกเต้าหู้หน่อไม้

summary: Stir-Fried Yard Long Beans with Pork
description: “Pad Prik Thua Fak Yao” ( ผัดพริกถั่วฝักยาว ) or “Pad Nam Prik Thua Fak Yao” ( ผัดน้ำพริกถั่วฝักยาว ) is a simple stir-fry where yard long beans and pork are stir-fried in a “Nam Prik” chili paste.
alternativeNames: Pad Nam Prik Thua Fak Yao
thaiName: ผัดพริกถั่วฝักยาว

summary: Stir-fried Lotus Root with Ground Pork
description: “Pad Rak Bua Mhu Sap” ( ผัดรากบัวหมูสับ ) is a simple Thai stir-fry dish where pre-cooked slices of lotus root are stir-fried together with ground pork and optionally with other vegetables or mushrooms. The dish is seasoned with garlic, Thai chilies, and a mixture of oyster sauce, fish sauce, and soy sauce.
thaiName: ผัดรากบัวหมูสับ

summary: Fried Egg Noodles with Soy Sauce
description: “Pad See Ew Ba Mee” ( ผัดซีอิ๊วบะหมี่ ) is a stir-fried dish made with egg noodles, meat, Chinese broccoli, eggs, and various types of soy sauce. The dish is also known by the shortened name “Pad See Ew Mee” ( ผัดซีอิ๊วหมี่ ).
thaiName: ผัดซีอิ๊วบะหมี่

description: “Pad See Ew Sen Yai” ( ผัดซีอิ๊วเส้นใหญ่ ), or simply “Pad See Ew” ( ผัดซีอิ๊ว ), wide rice noodles are fried together with meat and Chinese broccoli in soy sauce. Typical types of meat are pork or chicken.
thaiName: ผัดซีอิ๊วเส้นใหญ่

summary: Stir-Fried Glass Noodles with Soy Sauce
description: “Pad See Ew Woon Sen” ( ผัดซีอิ๊ววุ้นเส้น ) is a variation of the well-known stir-fry dish Pad See Ew in which narrow glass noodles are used instead of the usual wide rice noodles. The dish can also be found under the reversed name “Woon Sen Pad See Ew” ( วุ้นเส้นผัดซีอิ๊ว ).
thaiName: ผัดซีอิ๊ววุ้นเส้น

description:
“Pad Tao Hu Moo Sap” ( ผัดเต้าหู้หมูสับ ) is a Thai wok dish with minced pork and diced firm tofu. Both are stir-fried with a paste made from garlic, shallots, galangal, coriander root, Thai chilies and white peppercorns, then deglazed with a mixture of fish sauce, light soy sauce, Golden Mountain sauce and some chicken broth.
Vegetables can also be mixed in as desired. There are also variations where scrambled eggs are added during stir-frying, which is then called “Pad Tao Hu Moo Sap Sai Khai” ( ผัดเต้าหู้หมูสับใส่ไข่ ).
thaiName: ผัดเต้าหู้หมูสับ

description:
"Pad Thai" ( ผัดไทย ) is a popular street food dish made from rice noodles with meat or prawns, eggs and tofu. All of this is seasoned with a sauce made from tamarind, fish sauce, chilli and lime juice, which gives the dish its characteristic sweet and sour flavour. Pad Thai is typically served with ground peanuts, fresh sprouts and coriander.
The dish has an exciting history, as it was first popularised under the name ‘Pad Thai’ in the late 1930s. The then Prime Minister Luang Phibul Songkhram declared the dish, which had arrived in the country in a similar form with Chinese immigrants a long time ago, to be the national dish. On the one hand, this was intended to counteract a rice shortage, and on the other, the dish was supposed to give the then still young nation a common cultural identity.
thaiName: ผัดไทย

summary: Stir-fried rice noodles in an omelette
description: The “Pad Thai Hor Khai” ( ผัดไทยห่อไข่ ) is a variation of the well-known noodle dish “Pad Thai”, which is usually served in an artfully folded omelette. The dish can also be found under the inverted name “Pad Thai Khai Hor” ( ผัดไทยไข่ห่อ ).
thaiName: ผัดไทยห่อไข่

description: "Pad Thai Moo" ( ผัดไทยหมู ) is a stir-fried dish made from rice noodles with pork, vegetables and beaten eggs. The dish gets its characteristic taste from a sauce made from tamarind paste, fish sauce and chili. The classic side dishes are chopped peanuts, mung bean sprouts and fresh coriander.
thaiName: ผัดไทยหมู

description: “Pad Thai Rai Sen” ( ผัดไทยไร้เส้น ) is the name given to a Pad Thai without noodles. Surprisingly, many recipes use little to no tamarind paste. I think the reason for this is the lack of noodles, which normally absorb and balance out the acidity of the paste.
thaiName: ผัดไทยไร้เส้น

transcription: Pad Woon Sen Cha Om Goong
summary: Fried glass noodles with prawns and acacia shoots
description: Pad Woon Sen Cha Om Goong" ( ผัดวุ้นเส้นชะอมกุ้ง ) is fried glass noodles mixed with acacia shoots, prawns and egg. The whole thing is seasoned with a mixture of soy sauce, oyster sauce and fish sauce. The dish can also be found under the name “Woon Sen Pad Cha Om Sai Goong” ( วุ้นเส้นผัดชะอมใส่กุ้ง ).
alternativeNames: Pad Wun Sen Cha Om Gung
Woon Sen Pad Cha Om Sai Goong
thaiName: ผัดวุ้นเส้นชะอมกุ้ง

summary: Stir-fried glass noodles with vegetables and Prawns
description: Pad Woon Sen Goong" ( ผัดวุ้นเส้นกุ้ง ) is a simple wok dish in which glass noodles are fried together with vegetables and prawns. The dish is then flavoured with a mixture of soy sauce, oyster sauce, Golden Mountain sauce, white pepper and a pinch of sugar.
thaiName: ผัดวุ้นเส้นกุ้ง

description: In “Pad Woon Sen Normai Farang” ( ผัดวุ้นเส้นหน่อไม้ฝรั่ง ), glass noodles are stir-fried together with green asparagus and some garlic in a wok. Everything is then mixed with scrambled eggs and seasoned with a mixture of oyster sauce, soy sauce and fish sauce. The dish is also found under the name “Woon Sen Pad Khai Kap Normai Farang” ( วุ้นเส้นผัดไข่กับหน่อไม้ฝรั่ง ).
alternativeNames: Woon Sen Pad Khai Kap Normai Farang
thaiName: ผัดวุ้นเส้นหน่อไม้ฝรั่ง

description: "Pak Khad Dong" ( ผักกาดดอง ) is mustard cabbage that is pickled in brine with garlic and sometimes other spices. During fermentation, it develops a sour aroma similar to our sauerkraut or Korean kimchi. Pickled mustard greens are mainly used in northern Thai cuisine as a side dish with pork dishes, soups, or as an ingredient in wok dishes. This side dish is also known by its shortened name “Pak Dong” ( ผักดอง ).
thaiName: ผักกาดดอง

description: “Pak Khad Kaau Pad Gai” ( ผักกาดขาวผัดไก่ ) is a quick wok dish where Chinese cabbage is stir-fried together with garlic, possibly chilis and chicken, and then finished with a mixture of soy, fish and oyster sauce plus some sugar. The dish can also be found under the name “Pad Phak Khad Khaau Sai Gai” ( ผัดผักกาดขาวใส่ไก่ ).
alternativeNames: Pad Phak Khad Khaau Sai Gai
Phad Phak Khad Khaau Sai Kai
Phad Phak Kad Khao Sai Kai
thaiName: ผักกาดขาวผัดไก่

transcription: Pak Khad Kaau Pad Plaa Muek Haeng
summary: Stir-Fried Chinese Cabbage with Dried Squid
description: “Pak Khad Kaau Pad Plaa Muek Haeng” ( ผักกาดขาวผัดปลาหมึกแห้ง ), which is often simply called “Pad Pak Khad Kaau” ( ผัดผักกาดขาว ), is a quick wok dish where Chinese cabbage is stir-fried together with garlic and dried squid.
alternativeNames: Pak Khad Kaau Pad Plaa Mük Haeng
Pak Khad Kow Phat Pla Muek Haeng
thaiName: ผักกาดขาวผัดปลาหมึกแห้ง

summary: Stir-Fried Cabbage with Minced Meat and Tofu
description: “Pak Khad Tao Hu Moo” ( ผักกาดเต้าหู้หมู ) is a quick wok dish where fried tofu and minced meat are stir-fried together with a type of mustard green such as pak choi or Chinese cabbage.
thaiName: ผักกาดเต้าหู้หมู

description: “Pak Nam Saa” ( ผักน้ำส้า ) is a salad with Asian Pennywort or watercress. The herb used is mixed with tomatoes and shallots and dressed with a mixture of chili powder, fermented soybean paste, fresh galangal and roasted sesame oil.
thaiName: ผักน้ำส้า

description: “Phla Goong” ( พล่ากุ้ง ) is a salad with prawns, lemongrass, shallots and other herbs in a dressing made from lime juice, fish sauce and nam prik pao. Originally, raw prawns were used, which were then cooked in the acid of the lime juice, similar to Latin American ceviche. Nowadays, however, the seafood is usually stir-fried before preparing the salad.
thaiName: พล่ากุ้ง

description: Phla Hoi Shell" ( พล่าหอยเชลล์ ) is a salad with scallops and fresh herbs. These are dressed with a mixture of lemongrass, fish sauce and lime juice
thaiName: พล่าหอยเชลล์

description: “Phla Nuea” ( พล่าเนื้อ ) is a salad with beef, lots of lemongrass and other herbs in a dressing with lime juice and fish sauce or Nam Prik Pao. Originally, raw beef was used for this dish, which was then cooked in the citric acid similar to Latin American ceviche. Nowadays, however, the beef is usually at least seared until pink.
thaiName: พล่าเนื้อ

description: “Phla Plaa Muek Thod” ( พล่าปลาหมึกทอด ) is a salad with fried squid, lemongrass and fresh herbs. It is dressed with a dressing made from fish sauce, nam prik pao, palm sugar and lime juice. The salad is also known by the name “Phla Plaa Muek Grob” ( พล่าปลาหมึกกรอบ ).
thaiName: พล่าปลาหมึกทอด

description: “Pho Pia Thod” ( เปาะเปี๊ยะทอด ) is the name of the deep-fried spring rolls made from rice paper in Thailand. They are filled with a mixture of vegetables, glass noodles and often meat or prawns. They are usually served with a sweet chilli sauce or a peanut sauce. The spring rolls are often simply called “Pho Pia” ( เปาะเปี๊ยะ ). The Thai name was taken from the Chinese word for spring roll 薄饼 (Bó Bǐng).
thaiName: เปาะเปี๊ยะทอด

description: Phra Ram Long Song" ( พระรามลงสรง ) is pork or chicken served with a peanut sauce on a bed of green vegetables such as water spinach or spinach. The name of the dish can be translated as “Bathing King Rama” (พระราม = Pra Ram), ลงสรง = to bathe). The name Pra Ram refers to the protagonist of the “Ramakian Epic”. He is depicted in many illustrations with green skin .
thaiName: พระรามลงสรง

description: “Pik Gai Thod” ( ปีกไก่ทอด ) is what deep-fried chicken wings are called in Thailand. These are usually marinated before frying. A marinade of fish sauce, coriander roots, pepper and garlic is very popular.
thaiName: ปีกไก่ทอด

summary: Deep-Fried Chicken Wings With Fish Sauce
description: “Pik Gai Thod Nam Plaa” ( ปีกไก่ทอดน้ำปลา ) are deep-fried chicken wings. These are marinated with fish sauce and white pepper before frying and then dusted with starch.
thaiName: ปีกไก่ทอดน้ำปลา

description: “Plaa Dad Deaw” ( ปลาแดดเดียว ) refers to marinated fish that is dried in the sun. Before eating, the dried fish is usually deep-fried. When a specific type of fish is used, its exact name can be included in the dish name. The image above shows a modern interpretation with salmon, which would therefore be called “Plaa Salmon Dad Deaw” ( ปลาแซลมอนแดดเดียว ).
thaiName: ปลาแดดเดียว

transcription: Plaa Ga Phong Pad Tao Jiaw
summary: Stir-Fried Sea Bass with Fermented Soy Beans
description: “Plaa Ga Phong Pad Tao Jiaw” ( ปลากะพงผัดเต้าเจี้ยว ) is a wok dish with sea bass or other firm, white fish. It is stir-fried in a sauce made from yellow bean paste, sesame oil, pepper and oyster sauce. Often the fish is also accompanied by vegetables, mushrooms or chilis.
alternativeNames: Pla Ga Phong Pad Tao Jiaw
thaiName: ปลากะพงผัดเต้าเจี้ยว

description: Plaa Lek Thod Grob" ( ปลาเล็กทอดกรอบ ) are dried or fresh anchovies that are deep-fried until they are crispy. If dried fish is used, it must be soaked briefly before frying, but not seasoned at all, as it has already been dried with salt. Fresh fish is usually seasoned with fish sauce and coated in flour before deep-frying.
thaiName: ปลาเล็กทอดกรอบ

description: “Plaa Muek Nueng Manao” ( ปลาหมึกนึ่งมะนาว ) is steamed or sometimes boiled squid served in a sauce made from lime juice, chilis, garlic and other spices.
thaiName: ปลาหมึกนึ่งมะนาว

description: "Plaa Muek Pad Kapi" ( ปลาหมึกผัดกะปิ ) is a stir-fried dish with squid and shrimp paste. The squid rings or pieces are fried in a paste made from chilis, shallots, garlic, white pepper and shrimp paste. They are then deglazed with a mixture of oyster sauce, fish sauce and sugar before being mixed with spring onions and pickled garlic.
thaiName: ปลาหมึกผัดกะปิ

transcription: Plaa Muek Pad Nam Prik Pao
description: “Plaa Muek Pad Nam Prik Pao” ( ปลาหมึกผัดน้ำพริกเผา ) is squid that is stir-fried together with the chili paste “nam prik pao” and then mixed with holy basil and possibly some vegetables.
alternativeNames: Pla Muek Pad Nam Prik Pao
Plaa Muek Phad Nam Prik Pao
Pla Meuk Pad Nam Prik Paw
thaiName: ปลาหมึกผัดน้ำพริกเผา

description: “Plaa Muek Ping” ( ปลาหมึกปิ้ง ) or “Plaa Muek Yang” ( ปลาหมึกย่าง ) is the name given to grilled squid in Thailand. It can be whole tubes or skewers with tentacles. The squid is usually served with a spicy sauce.
thaiName: ปลาหมึกปิ้ง

description: “Plaa Muek Yad Sai” ( ปลาหมึกยัดไส้ ) refers to whole squid tubes that are stuffed with minced meat and then grilled or fried. The filling is seasoned with garlic, black pepper, coriander roots as well as oyster sauce and fish sauce and bound with an egg. The dish can also be found under the name “Plaa Muek Yad Pad Gratiam Prik Thai” ( ปลาหมึกยัดผัดกระเทียมพริกไทย ).
alternativeNames: Plaa Muek Yad Pad Gratiam Prik Thai
thaiName: ปลาหมึกยัดไส้

summary: Steamed Fish With Pumpkin and Herbs
description: In “Plaa Nueng” ( ปลานึ่ง ) from Isaan, fish is marinated in a simple paste of garlic, pepper and coriander roots and then steamed together with lemongrass, galangal and pumpkin or other vegetables.
thaiName: ปลานึ่ง (อีสาน)

description: Bei “Plaa Nueng Jeaw Makuea Thet” ( ปลานึ่งแจ่วมะเขือเทศ ) is steamed fish, served with raw vegetables and a spicy tomato dip. Before steaming, the fish is stuffed with herbs such as lemongrass, galangal and kaffir lime leaves.
thaiName: ปลานึ่งแจ่วมะเขือเทศ

summary: Steamed whole fish with lime and chili
description: The “Plaa Nueng Manao” ( ปลานึ่งมะนาว ) is a whole fish that is steamed in hot steam. It is poured with a sauce made of chili, garlic, coriander and lime juice and served with lime wedges. In northern Thailand, this dish is called “Plaa Nak Manao” ( ปลานัจมะนาว ).
thaiName: ปลานึ่งมะนาว

description: “Plaa Nueng See Ew” ( ปลานึ่งซีอิ๊ว ) is steamed white fish topped with a dark sauce. For the sauce, garlic and ginger are stir-fried and deglazed with a mixture of soy sauce, oyster sauce, Chinese cooking wine, sesame oil, and a bit of sugar. The flavor of the sauce can also be intensified with shiitake mushrooms. There are also variations of this dish where garlic and ginger are simply steamed together with the fish.
thaiName: ปลานึ่งซีอิ๊ว

transcription: Plaa Pad Khing Gap Hed Hoo Noo
summary: Stir-Fried Fish with Ginger and Wood Ear Mushrooms
description: “Plaa Pad Khing Gap Hed Hoo Noo” ( ปลาผัดขิงกับเห็ดหูหนู ) is a stir-fried dish from Central Thailand where fish is stir-fried with ginger and wood ear mushrooms. The fish is first briefly blanched, then stir-fried together with a simple paste made from garlic and pepper, before being mixed with the ginger and mushrooms. The dish is seasoned with fish sauce and palm sugar. This dish can also be found under the shortened name “Plaa Pad Khing” ( ปลาผัดขิง ).
alternativeNames: Pla Pad Khing Gap Hed Hu Nu
thaiName: ปลาผัดขิงกับเห็ดหูหนู

description: “Plaa Pad Khuen Chai” ( ปลาผัดขึ้นฉ่าย ) is a wok dish where pieces of fish fillet are stir-fried with garlic and then cooked in a mixture of oyster sauce, soy sauce, yellow bean paste and some broth. It is garnished with Thai celery and chilis before serving.
thaiName: ปลาผัดขึ้นฉ่าย

transcription: Plaa Pad Phed Prik Thai On
summary: Spicy Stir-Fried Fish with Green Pepper
description:
“Plaa Pad Phed Prik Thai On” ( ปลาผัดเผ็ดพริกไทยอ่อน ) is a wok dish where fish is stir-fried together with galangal, chilis, Thai aubergines, snake beans and fresh green pepper in red curry paste. It is finished with fish sauce and some sugar and garnished with Thai basil.
The dish is also known by the shortened name “Plaa Pad Phed” ( ปลาผัดเผ็ด ) or in reverse order as “Pad Phed Plaa” ( ผัดเผ็ดปลา ). The name can also include the specific designation of the type of fish, such as “Pad Phed Plaa Grai” ( ผัดเผ็ดปลากราย ).
alternativeNames: Plaa Pad Phed Phrik Thai On
Pla Pad Phed Phrik Thai On
thaiName: ปลาผัดเผ็ดพริกไทยอ่อน

description: In “Plaa Raad Prik Saam Rot” ( ปลาราดพริกสามรส ), a whole fish is grilled or deep-fried and then served with a sweet-sour-salty sauce made from Saam Gler, chilis, tamarind, fish sauce, and palm sugar. In English, it is often found under the names “Three Taste Fish” or “Three Flavor Fish.”
alternativeNames: Plaa Thod Saam Rot (ปลาทอดสามรส)
Plaa Tam Tim Thod Raad Prik Saam Rot (ปลาทัมทิมทอดราดพริกสามรส)
thaiName: ปลาราดพริกสามรส

description: “Plaa Rad Prik Sod” ( ปลาราดพริกสด ) is deep-fried or grilled fish that is topped with a chili sauce, made of fresh chilis and other ingredients. The dish with deep-fried fish can also be found under the name “Plaa Thod Rad Prik” ( ปลาทอดราดพริก ).
thaiName: ปลาราดพริกสด

summary: Deep-fried Fish with Garlic and Pepper
description:
“Plaa Thod Gratiam Prik Thai” ( ปลาทอดกระเทียมพริกไทย ) is deep-fried fish seasoned with chopped garlic and crushed peppercorns. In Thailand, catfish or other whole fish are usually used for this dish.
If a specific type of fish is used, its name is sometimes added to the “Plaa,” for example, “Plaa Nam Noeng Thod Gratiam Prik Thai” ( ปลาน้ำเงินทอดกระเทียมพริกไทย ) or “Plaa Nuea On Thod Krathiam Phrik Thai” ( ปลาเนื้ออ่อนทอดกระเทียมพริกไทย ).
thaiName: ปลาทอดกระเทียมพริกไทย

description: “Plaa Thod Sot Thakrai” ( ปลาทอดซอสตะไคร้ ) is grilled or deep-fried fish served with a sauce made from lemongrass, shallots, tamarind, soy sauce and palm sugar. The dish is also known by the names “Plaa Thod Thakrai” ( ปลาทอดตะไคร้ ) or “Plaa Jae Khon Thakrai” ( ปลาเจ๊ขนตะไคร้ ).
alternativeNames: Plaa Thod Yam Thakrai (ปลาทอดยำตะไคร้)
Plaa Jae Khon Thakrai (ปลาเจ๊ขนตะไคร้)
thaiName: ปลาทอดซอสตะไคร้

description: "Plaa Tom Kha Min" ( ปลาต้มขมิ้น ) is a clear fish soup from Southern Thailand, where fresh turmeric provides the characteristic flavor and color. Turmeric, shallots, galangal, garlic, lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves, and chilis are first pounded into a coarse paste and then cooked in a fish or chicken broth. The fish is added only near the end.
thaiName: ปลาต้มขมิ้น

description: Dishes from the bookThe titles and page numbers correspond to the English edition of the book. Unfortunately, I don’t know if they match those of the German edition, as I don’t have it to hand.
Dishes from the book

summary: Crab with Glass Noodles in a Clay Pot
description: “Poo Op Woon Sen” ( ปูอบวุ้นเส้น ) is made by baking crab and glass noodles with a paste of garlic, cilantro roots and black pepper, along with a mixture of various sauces in a clay pot. During cooking, the noodles absorb the flavor of the crab and the spicy aromas of the paste and sauces, resulting in a particularly intense taste.
thaiName: ปูอบวุ้นเส้น

description: “Poo Pad Pong Gari” ( ปูผัดผงกะหรี่ ) is a Thai dish where crab meat is stir-fried in a mixture of yellow curry powder, egg and coconut milk. The crabs usually remain in their shells, so the crab meat must be extracted while eating. This dish is also found under the name “Poo Ma Pad Pong Gari” ( ปูม้าผัดผงกะหรี่ ) when made with blue crabs.
thaiName: ปูผัดผงกะหรี่

description: "Prik Bon" ( พริกป่น ) is the Thai term for chili powder, which is made by grinding dried chilis. Especially in northern Thailand, the chilis are often roasted before grinding. Chili powder made from roasted chilis is called “Prik Bon Khua” ( พริกป่นคั่ว ) and gives dishes not only heat but also roasted aromas.
thaiName: พริกป่น

summary: Spice mix for Northern Thai Salads
description: Prik Laap" ( พริกลาบ ) is a northern Thai spice mixture that is used for Laab Khua, other northern Thai Laap variations and other dishes. In addition to dried chilies, it consists of a variety of spices, including coriander seeds, long pepper and white cardamom. The exact composition can vary depending on the recipe. All ingredients are ground in a mortar to a coarse powder or a coarse paste.
thaiName: พริกลาบ

description:
In Thailand, “prik nam plaa” ( พริกน้ำปลา ) refers to chilis (prik) cut into rings and marinated in fish sauce (“nam plaa”). In addition to the chilis, this simple spicy sauce can also contain other ingredients such as garlic or a little lime juice.
A jar of prik nam plaa can be found on every table in many restaurants in Thailand and is an indicator of the authenticity of Thai restaurants. Sometimes this sauce is also called “Nam Plaa Prik” ( น้ำปลาพริก ).
thaiName: พริกน้ำปลา

description: “Prik Nam Som” ( พริกน้ำส้ม ) are larger, milder Thai chilies that are pickled in vinegar. This simple spicy sauce can be prepared with rice vinegar or other types of vinegar. Prik Nam Som is often used to round off the taste of noodle and rice dishes or soups. For example, a version with yellow chilies is particularly popular as a side dish to rad na dishes.
thaiName: พริกน้ำส้ม

description: “Prik Thod Grob” ( พริกทอดกรอบ ) are seasoned chilis that are offered as a snack in Thailand. These are dried chilis that are soaked, then coated with salt, sesame seeds, and sticky rice flour before being deep-fried until crispy.
thaiName: พริกทอดกรอบ

summary: Noodles or rice with thick sauce
description:
Rad Na" ( ราดหน้า ) refers to various noodle dishes that are served with a sauce thickened with starch. The sauce is prepared from broth, yellow bean paste, white pepper, soy sauce and other ingredients and contains meat and vegetables. Typically, rad na is prepared with pork and Chinese broccoli, but there are also variations prepared with poultry, seafood or mushrooms and other vegetables.
Rad Na originally comes from the southern Chinese Teochew cuisine and was brought to Thailand by Chinese immigrants. It is closely related to the Cantonese dish “Wat Tan Hor” (滑蛋河), which also consists of a thick sauce poured over noodles. In Thailand, the dish has been adapted to the locally available ingredients and the tastes of the local population.
The names of the respective dishes are usually based on the type of noodles used or the type of meat. For example, “Sen Yai Rad Na” ( เส้นใหญ่ราดหน้า ) is served on wide rice noodles. There are also variations with rice, which are then called “Khao Rad Na ( ข้าวราดหน้า ). The dish is also often called “Lad Na”, which corresponds to the Laotian pronunciation of the dish and is widespread in Isaan.
thaiName: ราดหน้า

summary: Crispy Fried Noodles with Thick Gravy
description: “Rad Na Mee Grob” ( ราดหน้าหมี่กรอบ ) consists of deep-fried egg noodles topped with a thick gravy. The gravy is prepared from yellow bean paste, broth, white pepper, various other spices, and cornstarch, and contains meat and vegetables. Typically, the meat is pork, but the dish can also be prepared with chicken.
thaiName: ราดหน้าหมี่กรอบ

description: “Rad Na Tao Hu” ( ราดหน้าเต้าหู้ ) is a noodle dish where different types of noodles are covered with a thick gravy. The gravy is made from yellow bean paste, broth, white pepper, various other spices, and starch, and contains tofu as the main protein source as well as various types of vegetables. The dish is a popular vegetarian variation of Rad Na.
thaiName: ราดหน้าเต้าหู้

description: The “Sa Loem Jin Yang” ( สเลิ้มจิ้นย่าง ) is a Northern Thai salad with grilled pork. The meat here, unlike for example with “Nam Tok Mhu Yang”, is crushed with a hammer or in a mortar after grilling. Meat crushed with a hammer is also called “Jin Dup” ( จิ้นตุ๊บ ) in Northern Thailand.
thaiName: สเลิ้มจิ้นย่าง

description: The “Saa Khao Griap” ( ส้าข้าวเกรียบ ) is a somewhat unusual salad from northern Thailand, which is prepared from soaked rice paper . This is mixed with black sesame seeds, snake beans, chilli paste and fish sauce. The salad is also known as “Yum Khao Griap” ( ยำข้าวเกรียบ ) or “Yum Khao Khaep” ( ยำข้าวแคบ ).
thaiName: ส้าข้าวเกรียบ

description: For “Saa Makuea” ( ส้ามะเขือ ) from northern Thailand, fried or grilled pork or fish is pounded in a mortar, spiced hot and then mixed with finely chopped Thai eggplants and fresh herbs.
thaiName: ส้ามะเขือ

description: “Saa Moo” ( ส้าหมู ) is a Northern Thai dish where pork or pork offal is seasoned with Prik Laap and served together with shallots, some broth and fresh herbs. Typical herbs used include long coriander, Vietnamese coriander, mint, holy basil or lemon basil.
thaiName: ส้าหมู

description:
Saa Nuea ( ส้าเนื้อ ) is a northern Thai dish where raw or rare beef is seasoned with Prik Laap mixture and served together with shallots, some broth and fresh herbs. Popular herbs include long coriander, Vietnamese coriander, peppermint, holy basil or lemon basil.
There are also variations of this dish that use offal and are seasoned with blood, bile or the partly digested contents of the first stomach of cattle. The various variations are also known under the name “Saa Jin” (ส้าจิ๊น).
thaiName: ส้าเนื้อ

description: “Saam gler” ( สามเกลอ ) or “saam sahai” ( สามสหาย ) is the name given to a paste in Thailand, made from garlic, coriander roots and white or black peppercorns. Both names can be translated as “three best friends” and express how well these three spices harmonize with each other. This paste forms the basis for a lot of Thai dishes.
thaiName: สามเกลอ (สามสหาย)

description: Dishes from the book
In “Sai Bua Pad Goong” ( สายบัวผัดกุ้ง ) from Central Thailand, lotus stems are stir-fried together with shrimp in a simple sauce made from fish sauce, oyster sauce, and yellow bean paste.
thaiName: สายบัวผัดกุ้ง

description: "Sai Krok" ( ไส้กรอก ) or “Sai Krok Isaan” ( ไส้กรอกอีสาน ) is a sausage made from pork and rice that is usually fermented in the sun. The fermentation creates a slightly sour taste. It is made in the sausage form we are used to, but also in the form of small balls. Sai Krok is often served as a snack together with fresh chilis, ginger, shallots and cabbage.
thaiName: ไส้กรอก (อีสาน)

description: Sai Ua" ( ไส้อั่ว ) is a pork sausage prepared with a more or less spicy mixture of chilies, herbs and spices. This northern Thai sausage originally comes from the Shan State in Myanmar, but is now popular throughout Thailand. It is often produced as a sausage snail and is therefore very easy to recognize at markets.
thaiName: ไส้อั่ว

description:
“Salad Kaek” ( สลัดแขก ) is a mixed Thai salad that has its origins in Indian and Indonesian cuisine. It consists of a variety of fresh and cooked ingredients, such as chicken breast, bean sprouts, green lettuce, cucumbers, tomatoes, hard-boiled eggs and fried potato sticks or potato chips. The salad is served with a peanut dressing and mixed at the table by diners themselves.
The dish is also found under the name “Salad Satai Musalim” ( สลัดสไตล์มุสลิม ), which means “salad in Muslim style”.
thaiName: สลัดแขก

summary: Southern Thai Salad with Many Ingredients
description: “Salad Talee-Sap” ( สลัดทะเลสาบ ) is a southern Thai salad from Songkhla Province, named after Talee-Sap Lake. It combines a wild mix of ingredients such as pork loin, pork belly, hard-boiled eggs, tofu, shrimp, rice noodles, and various vegetables. These are tossed with a dressing made from fish sauce, sweet soy sauce, palm sugar, rice vinegar, and Thai chilis.
thaiName: สลัดทะเลสาบ

description:
Salapao ( ซาลาเปา ) are Thai buns or dumplings made from a soft, slightly sweet yeast dough. They are filled with various fillings of meat, seafood or vegetables and then steamed. A very popular filling is for example “Moo Daeng”.
They are the Thai variant of Chinese “Baozi” and probably came to Thailand with Chinese immigrants. Salapao are widespread throughout Thailand and are often eaten as breakfast, snack or meal in between.
thaiName: ซาลาเปา

description: "Sangkhaya Fak Thong" ( สังขยาฟักทอง ) is a kind of custard made from coconut milk, eggs, palm sugar, pandan leaves, and a pinch of salt. This mixture is poured into a hollowed-out pumpkin and steamed over hot water. The dish is also known by the reversed name “Fak Thong Sangkhaya” ( สังขยาฟักทอง).
thaiName: สังขยาฟักทอง

transcription: Sapagetti Pad Ga Prau Moo Sap
summary: Pasta with Minced Meat and Holy Basil
description: “Sapagetti Pad Ga Prau Mhu Sap” ( สปาเก็ตตี้ผัดกะเพราหมูสับ ) is a modern interpretation of the well-known dish “Pad Gra Prau Mhu Sap”, in which minced meat is mixed with western spaghetti. As with the original, the meat is seasoned with crushed garlic and chilis as well as various sauces and holy basil.
alternativeNames: Sapagetti Pad Ga Prau Mhu Sap
Sapagetti Pad Ka Prau Moo Sap
Sapagetti Pad Kra Pau Moo Sap
Sapagetti Pad Kra Pow Moo Sap
thaiName: สปาเก็ตตี้ผัดกะเพราหมูสับ

description: “Sapagetti Pad Kee Mao” ( สปาเก็ตตี้ผัดขี้เมา ) ist eine Variante der scharfen “Drunken Noodles” bei der statt Reisnudeln westliche Spaghetti verwendet werden.
thaiName: สปาเก็ตตี้ผัดขี้เมา

description: “Sapparot Nam Kati” ( สับปะรดน้ำกะทิ ) is a very simple Thai dessert where fresh pineapple is cooked in coconut milk and then served chilled with ice cubes. The coconut milk is seasoned with pandan, palm sugar and a pinch of salt.
thaiName: สับปะรดน้ำกะทิ

description: "Sen Lek Rad Na Gai" ( เส้นเล็กราดหน้าไก่ ) is a noodle dish made with thin rice noodles and chicken. The ingredients are cooked in a sauce made from yellow bean paste, fish sauce, soy sauce, and oyster sauce, that is thickened with cornstarch. Depending on the recipe, the dish can have either a thick sauce or a soup-like consistency.
thaiName: เส้นเล็กราดหน้าไก่

description: “Sen Yai” ( เส้นใหญ่ ) refers to very wide rice noodles in Thailand that are made from rice flour and tapioca starch. They are often used in wok dishes like Pad See Ew or Rad Na or also in noodle soups. The noodles have a soft but also slightly chewy texture and absorb the flavor of sauces very well.
thaiName: เส้นใหญ่

description:
“Sen Yai Pad Kee Mao” ( เส้นใหญ่ผัดขี้เมา ) is a Thai noodle dish, which is prepared with wide rice noodles (Sen Yai) and a paste made from garlic and chilies, as well as various sauces.
It is typically prepared with meats such as chicken, pork or seafood, as well as various vegetables, fresh green pepper and holy basil . The dish is known for its intense spiciness.
The name “Pad Kee Mao” is often translated as “drunken noodles”, alluding to the spiciness of the dish, which is said to alleviate hangovers or sober up drunks.
The dish is also known under the upside-down name “Pad Kee Mao Sen Yai” ( ผัดขี้เมาเส้นใหญ่ ) or as “Guai Tiao Pad Kee Mao” ( ก๋วยเตี๋ยวผัดขี้เมา ).
thaiName: เส้นใหญ่ผัดขี้เมา

summary: Wide Rice Noodles with thick Sauce
description: “Sen Yai Rad Na” ( เส้นใหญ่ราดหน้า ) consists of wide rice noodles served together with meat and Chinese broccoli in a sauce thickened with cornstarch and seasoned with fish sauce, soy sauce, oyster sauce and yellow bean paste. Pork is usually used as the meat. Depending on the recipe and amount of broth, it is more of a soup or a plate dish.
thaiName: เส้นใหญ่ราดหน้า

summary: Wide Rice Noodles with red Sauce
description: “Sen Yai Yentafo” ( เส้นใหญ่เย็นตาโฟ ) consists of thick rice noodles served in a sauce made from broth, fish sauce, vinegar and red, fermented tofu. They are usually served together with seafood and fish balls, sometimes also fried tofu. Depending on the recipe, blood tofu is also added to the dish and depending on the amount of broth, it is more of a soup or a plate dish.
thaiName: เส้นใหญ่เย็นตาโฟ

description: “Si Khrong Moo Thod” ( ซี่โครงหมูทอด ) are marinated pork ribs that are deep-fried in hot oil. They are a popular snack and are often served with alcoholic beverages. Ribs of this type are also called “Kra Dhuk Moo Thod” ( กระดูกหมูทอด ).
thaiName: ซี่โครงหมูทอด

transcription: Si Khrong Moo Thod Gratiam Prik Thai
summary: Deep-Fried Pork Ribs with Garlic and Peppercorns
description: “Si Khrong Moo Thod Gratiam Prik Thai” ( ซี่โครงหมูทอดกระเทียมพริกไทย ) are pork ribs that are deep-fried in hot oil until they are crispy on the outside. The ribs are marinated in various sauces and chopped garlic and crushed peppercorns before frying.
alternativeNames: Si Khrong Moo Thod Kratiam Phrik Thai
Si Khrong Moo Tod Kratiam Prik Thai
Si Krong Mu Thod Kra Tiam Prik Thai
thaiName: ซี่โครงหมูทอดกระเทียมพริกไทย

transcription: Si Khrong Moo Toon Tao Jiaw
summary: Braised Pork Ribs With Yellow Bean Paste
description: “Si Khrong Moo Toon Tao Jiaw” ( ซี่โครงหมูตุ๋นเต้าเจี้ยว ) are pork spare ribs that are braised in a sauce made from yellow bean paste, garlic, coriander roots, pepper, ginger and different types of soy sauce until the meat almost falls off the bones. Depending on the recipe, the ribs are cut into small pieces with a cleaver before braising. This dish of Chinese origin is also known as “Si Khrong Moo Ob Tao Jiaw” ( ซี่โครงหมูอบเต้าเจี้ยว ).
alternativeNames: Si Krong Moo Toon Tao Jiaw
Si Khrong Moo Toon Tao Jiao
Si Khrong Moo Ob Tao Jiao
thaiName: ซี่โครงหมูตุ๋นเต้าเจี้ยว

description: “Som Pak” ( ส้มผัก ) is a fairly simple Northern Thai salad. It is made from pickled mustard greens, fresh ginger, Thai eggplants, and chilis. In Central Thailand, this salad is also called “Pak Dong” ( ผักดอง ). Both names essentially just mean “pickled vegetables”.
thaiName: ส้มผัก

description: Som Tam Plueak Thaeng Mo" ( ส้มตำเปลือกแตงโม ) is a salad made from the rind of watermelons. The rind is cut into strips and crushed in a clay mortar together with garlic, chilies, palm sugar, limes, fish sauce, peanuts and tomatoes. There are also variations in which vegetables such as corn or yard long beans are mixed into the salad.
thaiName: ส้มตำเปลือกแตงโม

summary: Platter with Papaya Salad and Side Dishes
description: Som Tam Thad" ( ส้มตำถาด ) or “Tam Thad” for short ( ตำถาด ) is a large platter of Som Tam Thai in the middle with all kinds of side dishes, such as pork crusts, chicken wings, moo yor or other sausage, rice noodles, hard-boiled eggs and pickled vegetables around it.
thaiName: ส้มตำถาด

description:
Som Tam Thai" ( ส้มตำไทย ) is a salad in which unripe papaya cut into strips is pounded in a mortar together with ingredients such as garlic, chilis, fish sauce, palm sugar and peanuts. The pounding combines the different flavours of the ingredients.
The epithet “Thai” is used to distinguish this Som Tam variation from the original variations from Isaan in the north-east and those from Laos . In contrast to the som tam from central Thailand, these usually still use fermented fish sauce, but no peanuts and are usually significantly hotter.
thaiName: ส้มตำไทย

description:
“Som Tam Thod” ( ส้มตำทอด ) is a snack in which deep-fried papaya strips are served with a sauce made from garlic, chilis, fish sauce, palm sugar, dried prawns and peanuts. The unripe papaya strips are coated in a mixture of starch and rice flour before being deep-fried.
This is a deconstructed and reinterpreted Som Tam Thai. Depending on the recipe, other ingredients such as prawns are also deep-fried or vegetables such as snake beans or sweetcorn are added to the sauce.
thaiName: ส้มตำทอด

description:
“Suea Rong Hai” ( เสือร้องไห้ ) or “crying tiger” is a classic street food dish from Isaan. Grilled beef steak is served with a spicy sauce for dipping. There are many theories about the origin of the strange name, but none of them have been proven . The dish can also sometimes be found under the longer name “Nuea Yang Suea Rong Hai” ( เนื้อย่างเสือร้องไห้ ).
Rezepte
thaiName: เสือร้องไห้

summary: Dry stir-fried noodles with Sukiyaki Sauce
description: “Suki Haeng” ( สุกี้แห้ง ) is a stir-fried dish with fried noodles, which is indirectly inspired by the Japanese hotpot “Sukiyaki” and is prepared with the Thai version of suki sauce. Meat and vegetables are usually mixed into the noodles. The name component “Haeng” means “dry” and indicates that it is a stir-fried dish and no real Sukiyaki.
thaiName: สุกี้แห้ง

description: “Sup Hed Gra Dang” ( ซุปเห็ดกระด้าง ) is a spicy dip from Isaan. It is made from mushrooms, snake beans, pounded fish and some spices and fresh herbs. It is typically served with raw vegetables and sticky rice.
thaiName: ซุปเห็ดกระด้าง

description: "Sup Makham" ( ซุปมะขาม ) is a sour soup from Southern Thailand. This simple soup with Indian roots is prepared with tamarind, curry leaves, a masala spice blend, and various other spices. It is often served as a contrast to heavy curries.
thaiName: ซุปมะขาม

description: “Sup Normai” ( ซุปหน่อไม้ ) is a salad from Isaan prepared with bamboo shoots, fresh chilies or coarse chili powder, fresh herbs, yanang extract, fermented fish sauce, khao khua and lime juice. Like many dishes from Isaan, this dish has its origins in Laos.
thaiName: ซุปหน่อไม้

description:
“Sup Pak” ( ซุปผัก ) is a salad from Northern Thailand where blanched leafy vegetables are dressed with a paste made from garlic, chilis, and fermented fish sauce. The salad is typically garnished with fresh herbs, ginger, and sesame seeds.
The name “Sup” indicates the Lao origin of the salad, while “Pak” generally means “vegetables.”
thaiName: ซุปผัก

description: “Sup Thua Fak Yao” ( ซุปถั่วฝักยาว ) is a salad from Northern Thailand where yard long beans are mixed with roasted garlic, chilis and shallots, then pounded in a mortar. This salad is then dressed with fish sauce, Plaa Ra and lime juice. Depending on the recipe, grilled fish or meat may also be mixed with the beans.
thaiName: ซุปถั่วฝักยาว

description: Tam Khanun ( ตำขนุน ) is a northern Thai salad based on a paste made from garlic, chilis, galangal as well as Plaa Ra or shrimp paste. In this paste, young jackfruit is fried and then mixed with fresh herbs. There are several variations, for example the salad can also additionally contain minced meat, pork belly, tomatoes, cucumbers or a combination of these ingredients.
thaiName: ตำขนุน

summary: Salad with corn and other vegetables
description: The “Tam Khao Phot” ( ตำข้าวโพด ) is a Thai salad prepared with sweetcorn and other vegetables such as cucumber, tomatoes or snake beans . All ingredients are dressed with a mix of lime juice, fish sauce and palm sugar. Depending on the recipe, the salad is also called “Yum Khao Phot” ( ยำข้าวโพด ) or “Tam Thaeng Khao Phot” ( ตำแตงข้าวโพด ), when cucumber is used in addition to the corn.
thaiName: ตำข้าวโพด

summary: Salad with Sweetcorn and Vietnamese Sausage
description: “Tam Khao Phot Moo Yor” ( ตำข้าวโพดหมูยอ ) is a Thai salad prepared with sweetcorn, mhu yor and vegetables such as tomatoes, cucumber or snake beans. The salad is dressed with a mixture of lime juice, fish sauce and palm sugar. In some recipes, this salad is also called “Yam Khao Phot Moo Yor” ( ยำข้าวโพดหมูยอ ).
thaiName: ตำข้าวโพดหมูยอ

description: Tam Ponlamai" ( ตำผลไม้ ) is a Thai salad made from a mixture of different fruits. The fruits are served with a spicy dressing made from lime juice, fish sauce, palm sugar and chili powder. This salad combines sweet, sour and spicy flavors and is often garnished with peanuts or dried prawns. It can also be found under the name “Som Tam Ponlamai” ( ส้มตำผลไม้ ) or “Yam Ponlamai” ( ยำผลไม้ ) and “Yam Ponlamai Ruam” ( ยำผลไม้รวม ).
thaiName: ตำผลไม้

description:
Tam Strobori ( ตำสตรอเบอร์รี่ ) is a northern Thai salad prepared with strawberries. The preparation as well as the other ingredients correspond to those of a Som Tam, which leads to a really exciting flavour combination.
